column37: introduction
To sample the Kepler Track (a Great Walk) or for an easy overnight tramp for kids, follow this track through beech forest to Moturau Hut and Shallow Bay on Lake Manapori.

column3: Five Mile Bay and Awaroa Tracks
column37: These family friendly tracks stretch along the expanse of Five Mile Bay, and are great for either walking or biking.
Enjoy lovely forest and sea views on the Oromahoe Traverse, which follows a ridgeline through regenerating hardwood/podocarp forest, linking Oromahoe Road with School Road, near Paihia.
Take a short, easy walk around a dune lake with some great spots to enjoy views and look for/listen to birds - it's a good option for kids.
This is a classic mountain bike ride located in lower Ahuriri valley.
Several enjoyable walking tracks are located near Lake Benmore in the Waitaki valley.
An extension of the very popular Blue Pools Walk and connects with the Young River. It's  also an alternative, high river route to the stat of the Gillespie Pass Circuit.
This tramping track offers an excellent trip to the North Borland Hut in Monowai, Fiordland.
Iron Gate Hut is a good day's hike along a sidle track up the Oroua River valley. Longer tramps are possible from this hut. Stay a night and return the same way.
Walk through a fine example of the podocarp forest that once covered much of the central North Island - it's a suitable track for kids.
At the mouth of the Tauranga-Taupo River in the small village of Oruatua, there are two easy walking tracks to enjoy the river, the native bush of the reserves and the expansive lake views.
This lovely 3-km loop track leads through a grove of regenerating kauri and offers views of the Taheke Waterfall.
This track circles a beautiful lake surrounded by native forest and is a special favourite of tree lovers, birdwatchers, and families.
The Mokoroa Stream Track is a challenging loop walk which comes off the Goldie Bush Walkway.
For an easy walk head to the rocky shore where kids of all ages can explore tidal pools, or follow an old pioneer's track before continuing down the river to the coast.

column3: Seven Mile Track Wilson Bay Track
column37: Walk or bike through regenerating bush and pine forest with views of Wilson Bay.

column3: Kaitoke Hot Springs Track to Mt Hobson (Hirakimata)
column37: Kaitoke Hot Springs Track is a popular easy walk following the edge of the Kaitoke Swamp to sulphurous hot springs. Continue on the Peach Tree Track to Mt Hobson (Hirakimata).
This track is easily accessible and an interesting day or overnight trip.
A pleasant walk through regenerating forest to a lookout that offers stunning views over Waitangi, the Bay of Islands and Russell.

column3: Copland Track to Welcome Flat Hut
column37: This popular tramp gives a glimpse of Westland’s spectacular forest, river and mountain scenery, with natural hot pools at Welcome Flat an added attraction.
Climb above the bush line to the exposed alpine ridge of   Umukarikari and Mount Urchin. Enjoy fantastic views and access the Waipakihi valley and hut.
Enjoy impressive views of the glacier, the valley and Waiho River from the summit of this short steady climb.

From the caves, a 2-km walk leads you through a picturesque karst limestone landscape across farmland and regenerating bush to a point where you can take in the magnificent views. Within the entrance to the caves themselves, you will find stalactites, sta
Combine these tracks for a circuit walk from Whangaparapara.
Wairepo Kettleholes provide a feeding area for both native and introduced birds.
At 1800 metres on the Sealy Range, Mueller Hut provides a 360-degree panorama encompassing glaciers, ice cliffs, vertical rock faces and New Zealand’s highest peaks.

column11: One long or two shorter days
column37: An attractive, forest-lined river walk of three sections that has several natural features and access to good fishing.
Enjoy outstanding views of Mahinepua Peninsula, Matauri Bay and other forested islands of the Cavalli group from this walk along the ridge tops.
The track provides spectacular views of the Wairoa Valley to Ananui Falls. The central Kaimai Mamaku Forest Park is rich in cultural and historical remains including logging era relics.
This track traverses a range in the Lindis Conservation Area.
There are a variety of tramping routes from Wakarara road end in the Eastern Ruahine Forest Park, including Gold Creek and Barlow Hut.
Follow the Callery Gorge Walk as it climbs to a high terrace before descending to the Callery River.
From Lake Rotoroa car park, this track passes through a stand of kahikatea and around the lake outlet emerging on the road near Lake Rotoroa Lodge.
From Kumeti Road End in Eastern Ruahine Forest Park you can take tramping tracks to Opawe Rd and Kiritaki Hut.
This loop track provides options for an overnight tramp with children or a multi-day tramp.

column3: Fanthams Peak Panitahi and Syme Hut Track
column37: On a clear day this tramp offers great views up the mountain and down to the Taranaki Ring Plain and the coastline.
Enjoy panoramic views over mountains and alpine lakes on this half-day walk off Milford Road on the Routeburn Track - it's suitable families with children.
Experienced trampers can cross from Maratoto to Wentworth.

This route makes a good weekend trip, all against a backdrop of some of the best features of Arthur’s Pass National Park – glaciers, mountain peaks and ice-fed rivers. Crow Hut is at the bush edge in an alpine meadow.
Follow a 200 m track across the Ahuroa River and on to the picturesque Piroa Falls. The river has many suitable swimming holes along the track, making it a fun walk for children.
Walk along an enchanting moss carpet.
Whites Bay has walks for a range of abilities, including kids - there are  rocky areas for scrambling and exploring and a near-flat sandy beach that's excellent for swimming too.

column3: Tapotupotu Bay to Cape Reinga Te Rerenga Wairua
column37: Starting at Tapotupotu Bay, this 5 km track offers incredible views before descending into Sandy Bay and on to the Cape Reinga lighthouse. An option for families camping at Tapotupotu.
This tramping track follows a century-old trail in Deep Cove, Doubtful Sound, through mixed podocarp forest.
This short, easy forest walk passes by a reflective lake and crosses over glacial landforms - it's suitable for children.
Tasman River is a large braided river which flows into Lake Pukaki. There are walking and cycling tracks in the area.

column3: Dome Forest car park to Govan Wilson Rd Matakana
column37: A challenging longer walk (7 hrs) through regenerating native forest that is also part of Te Araroa, The Long Pathway. The track starts at the Dome carpark and ends at Govan Wilson Rd, Matakana.
Starting from Motutere Bay on the eastern shores of Lake Taupo take in the views, the native bush and the volcanic heritage of the area.
Walk through one of the best examples of semi coastal forest on the east coast of the North Island on this loop track - it's suitable for older children.
Climb 400 m on this steep loop track which traverses Powder Hill to see spectacular views of the Silver Peaks and Saddle Hill.
Macaulay valley can be accessed on foot, or by mountain bike, horse or 4WD.
The track starts from Opito Bay and splits into a series of short, easy walks suitable for children - visit a small beach in the Te Puna Inlet and a pa site on Tareha Point.
The Bain Bay Track travels through wetlands and around the lake shore to Bain Bay.

Egmont National Park’s premier 2–3 day tramp offers spectacular views of Mt Taranaki and the surrounding countryside. The 25 km track passes through forest, alpine tussock fields and the unique Ahukawakawa Swamp.

column3: Te Werahi Beach to Twilight Beach
column37: Experience gorgeous peach-coloured dunes, unusual dune grasses, and views of Cape Maria van Diemen and Motuopao Island on this 3-hour track to Twilight Beach.
Piwakawaka Track is easy walking track leading from the northern end of Elaine Bay to a small beach.

column11: 2 hr one way to river forks
column37: This challenging tramping route leads from the Milford Road, up the East Eglinton river valley through beech forest.
It takes half a day to climb to this beautiful sub-alpine tussock basin beneath Mt Earnslaw/Pikirakatahi.
Wairere Falls Track weaves its way through moss covered rocks and tree roots. Large round boulders form natural pools and cascading waterfalls.
This route travels the eastern and northern flanks of Arthur's Pass National Park. The sections through the upper Minchin Stream and Townsend Creek are more adventurous.
This walk, suitable for kids, leads across farmland to the site of the first mission settlement in New Zealand.
Pakihi Walk climbs through kamahi and rimu forest to a platform lookout.
Walk or mountain bike to Wharfedale Hut.

column3: Te Puia Hut Track and Mangatainoka Hot Springs
column37: Walk to Te Puia Hut for an easy overnight tramp, or continue on to hot springs surrounded by bush and with river views.
Head up the Waipakihi River Valley, a popular option for hunters to access the tops, or a great day out for swimming in the summer.
Fit and experienced trampers can cross the Remutaka Range via Papatahi (902 m) from mid-Orongorongo valley to the Wairarapa side of the Remutaka Forest Park.

column3: Cape Reinga Te Rerenga Wairua Lighthouse Walk
column37: Enjoy outstanding panoramic views and pay respect to a site steeped in Maori tradition on a short stroll to an iconic lighthouse - it's suitable for children and buggies.

column3: Franz Josef Glacier Ka Roimata o Hine Hukatere Walk
column37: Follow a rocky riverbed path, suitable for children, past a waterfall to Franz Josef Glacier viewing area.
Travel through expansive tussock downs, lush forests and nīkau palms to the roaring seas of the West Coast.
This walking track links up with two popular tracks within Catchpool Valley.
This short walk over a beautiful wetland has plenty of bird life and is great for kids.
Climb up to Mt Fishtail (1643 m) via Fishtail Hut.
Once extensively logged and mined, a regenerating coastal forest now greets visitors as they walk along the Waitaia Track.
This short easy walk takes you through manuka scrub passing a series of excavated gumholes. A historical outing suitable for families.
This short, easy walk leads to the coast and a lighthouse - it's a great option for kids.
The Motutara Recreation Reserve lies halfway between Russell and Whangarei. At the reserve you’ll find several small beaches and some good fishing and diving spots.
There are several tramping opportunities available in Croydon Bush Scenic Reserve.
Well-formed, Parata Walking Track is suitable for people of most ages and fitness levels. It climbs to a lookout offering views of the coast and Reikorangi Valley.

column3: Rangitane Road to Crow Hut Loop Track
column37: A very steep up and down tramp in Ruahine Forest Park, climbing first to the Mokai Patea Range, then dropping to the Kawhatau River and then back up to the Hikurangi Range and out to Rangitane Road via the Kawhatau River. Involves camping out.
Gertrude Saddle includes rocky alpine terrain and should only be attempted in good weather. Wet weather, snow or ice create treacherous conditions.
Take a short walk around Rangitoto Island Scenic Reserve. Stroll through a kowahi grove or glen of kidney ferns, or walk along the coast to a gull breeding colony.
Perfect for families and just a short drive from Taupo on SH5, explore native bush and discover local history in this scenic and historic reserve.

column3: Flora Hut and Mount Arthur Hut tracks
column37: Walk through beech forest to one of two huts, or combine the tracks for a circuit walk - a great day walk or overnight tramp for families with kids.
Discover a wide array of beautiful bush and mountain views.
Walk to an historic cottage (built 1897) that was home to a reclusive couple for nearly 40 years.
A walk with superb lake and mountain views over undulating open grassland and scattered scrub, ending at Jack's Point.
Explore New Zealand's history on this short, easy walk - it's suitable for buggies.
Walk to some excellent swimming holes on a track that follows an old tramline.
A highlight along this track is the extensive groves of nīkau nestled under tall tawa, kohekohe and pukatea forest.
Walk through a magnificant stand of native bush.

This route crosses Rabbit Pass to connect with the East branch of the Matukituki River. It is suitable for experienced alpine trampers. Only attempt in good conditions – even then extreme care is required.
Retracing an old gold-mining water race, this short walk passes through forest of young beech and rimu to mature podocarps - it's good for children but be sure to supervise them.
Walk to a lookout with extensive views.

column3: Diamond Lake and Rocky Mountain walks
column37: Choose from several walks including short, easier options suitable for kids, and enjoy views of Diamond Lake, Lake Wanaka and the surrounding mountains.

column3: J.M. Barker (Hapupu) National Historic Reserve Walk
column37: See Moriori rakau momori (tree carvings) on this bush walk.
See spectacular mountain scenery, forest and alpine vegetation, glacier-fed rivers and the Dart Glacier on the Rees-Dart Track.

This rugged and challenging track passes over some of Northland's highest points and offers occasional views over the surrounding forest and mountain range.  Listen to Kokako around the Oraora Saddle.
Walk the Mokoroa Falls Track to view the falls from a lookout platform. The track can be walked as part of a loop track when joined with the Mokoroa Stream Track and Goldie Bush Walkway.
Part of the original Waikawau to Kennedy Bay route used by gold miners and loggers. It goes up the main ridge past a series of lookouts giving views over bush covered hills to coast and islands.
From Kaweka Road you can access Makahu Saddle via Whittle Road. The saddle is a popular starting point for backcountry tramping trips.
Climb or moutain bike to Soldiers' Monument above Tomahawk Lagoon and take in commanding coastal views.
Visit a cute bivvy with an unusual curved roof.

Take a trip back into New Zealand's rail heritage while you walk or cycle an old coach road. The road was used to carry passengers and goods between two railheads on the North Island main trunk link before they were linked in 1908.
The Silver Peaks Scenic Reserve provides challenging routes in rugged country, less than 30 minutes drive from Dunedin city.
One of the most popular day trips in the park is the climb to Mountain House Shelter along the easy grade of the Gentle Annie Track.
Explore the coastal area around Papatowai - where forest meets sea.
Walk to the Hawke's Bay highest waterfall or choose another walk in an area where native forest and birds are protected from pests and predators - shorter options are suitable for children
The Broken Hills area has a number of walking tracks through old mining sites.
A challenging east-west crossing of the Kaimai Ranges featuring stream crossings and historic tramways.
This loop walk passes through regenerated native forest - it's well-graded and suitable for children.
The track runs between the Waterfall road carpark to the spectacular falls, where water surges out of fissures in a high cliff face.
Starting at the Cameron Creek car park enjoy a good day's tramp ending at the 4-bunk Cameron Hut.
Rokaiwhenua Stream Walk is a pleasant and easy 1-hour forest walk you get to from Tamaki Road end in Eastern Ruahine Forest.
This difficult tramping track leads from the Hollyford Road up to Lake Howden on the Routeburn Track.
Take a short, easy stroll along the Waiokukurau Stream to a picturesque lookout over a waterfall.
A tramping track leaves from the Fantail Bay campsite and leads to the bushline where you’ll find outstanding views.

column3: Knights Track to Pohangina Valley East Road
column37: There is a bit of everything on this tramp in the Ruahine Forest Park - open tops, rivers and bush travel.
Walk to the spectacular McLean Falls though a variety of forest and shrub types.
The 80-minute walk follows an old 4WD road then the tracks climbs to the old water tunnels. You will need a torch and raincoat to explore the tunnels.
This flat, easy walk or mountain bike ride, suitable for children, follows an old logging tramline and passes beautiful Lake Mahinapua.

The Roberts Point Track requires a good level of fitness. After walking one hour you will reach Hende's Hut. From there the track continues to climb on to Roberts Point where the glacier views are spectacular.

Observe seals and seabirds, explore historic pā and whaling sites and enjoy clifftop views of the sea and mountains. Suitable for families, the whole walkway takes three hours but you can also explore a range of shorter tracks.
Dramatic views of powerful waterfalls and water-sculpted shapes in the rocks will keep kids interested on this short, easy walk.

A seal colony, a lighthouse and panoramic views of mountains and coastline feature on this spectacular coastal walkway. With the beach close by as well it's a good option for children. It's also one of our best short walks.
Climb to the summit of this 468 m peak for views on clear day from the Inland Kaikoura Range in the south to Mt Taranaki in the north-west - it's a good option for older children.
This short loop walk from Kakaho Campsite takes in the fantastic views and the tall trees of the Pureora Forest.
Pass over Mt Sunday (1310 m) and Mt Riley (1314 m) on this circuit track.
This challenging trip above the bushline in Mt Richmond Forest Park offers outstanding views over the Waimea Plains and the Inland Kaikoura Ranges.
The tracks and routes in the Stafford Bay area can be challenging and are recommended for fit and well-equipped trampers.
On this easy, beautiful trail, you’ll enjoy panoramic views of the Pacific Ocean, Whakaari/White Island, Moutohora/Whale Island and towards East Cape.
This short kauri forest walk is gentle, making it suitable for children and an easy opportunity to enjoy the unique kauri forest environment.
Take the Waihoanga Gorge Kauri Walk as it makes its way through a range of forest species including puriri, taraire, nikau and virgin kauri trees.
Take the shortest track to Pahautea Hut and Pirongia summit.
Walk or mountain bike up the Godley valley.
This easy short track from Otamure Bay campsite leads to a sandy, secluded beach at Tauwhara Bay. Suitable for children.
Stroll to view the Pohuehue waterfall or complete the walkway or longer loop (Beverley Price Loop Track) through regenerating forest in the Pohuehue Scenic Reserve, just south of Warkworth.

column3: Crown Track to Dickey s Flat
column37: Take this short walk through historic mining country through to the Dickey Flat Campsite.

column3: Lotkow Road to Little s Clearing
column37: Lotkow Road branches off Whittle Road at the entry point to the Kaweka Forest Park.

Follow the banks of the Tongariro River alongside farmland and through native bush and urban areas, and enjoy magnificent river views - it's an easy, mainly flat track with multiple entry points so a great option for children.
These short walks are in the Egmont National Park, at North Egmont Road end.

The tailings on this walk are nationally significant as the only complete record of dredging activity from 1863 to 1963. They're an awe inspiring sight, hundreds of metres wide like a giant’s ploughed field.

column3: Pearl Harbour to Back Valley Hut Track
column37: A tramping track leading through beech forest to Back Valley Hut near Manapouri, with a side trip option to peaceful Lake Rakatu.
This route is for experienced trampers. It is irregularly marked, steep and in parts obscure and washed out.
Experience the Ananui Falls Track with delightful scenery along the way.
This short tramping track goes between Borland Lodge and 6km along the Borland Road, Monowai, Fiordland.
This track follows the Ahuriri River. Three huts on route provide several options.
Kohekohe Walk in Hemi Matenga Memorial Park Scenic Reserve is suitable for people of all ages and fitness levels. It links Tui Crescent to Kakariki Grove.

The walk up to Kirwans Hut is one of New Zealand's classic overnight tramps.  A three day loop can also be made by going down the Waitahu Valley.  There are incredible historic relics to be seen in this area.
This walkway to a bird hide, where you can easily view birdlife, is a great walk for children and families.

Take in breathtaking views over Lake Wanaka, Mount Aspiring/Tititea and surrounding peaks after a steep climb through alpine meadows and tussock grasslands to the summit. This is a popular track and one of our best day hikes.
Specifically designed dual use trail through native bush with great downhills and some decent climbs for the mountain bikers. Starts from the highest point in Whakarewarewa Forest.
Rock shelters, an open tussock plateau and tops with superb views, combine to make this an interesting overnight tramp with options for children.
This easy, well graded walking track from the Hollyford Road takes you on a short climb through rainforest to the lookout of the impressive Humboldt Falls.
This flat and well-formed track passes through native podocarp-hardwood forest and has a variety of birds - with a picnic table at the start, it's a good option for families.

column3: Twelve Mile Delta to Bob s Cove Track
column37: Follow the shore of Lake Wakatipu and enjoy lake views, native bush and ancient marine sediments. Twelve Mile Delta was a location for Lord of the Rings' Ithilien Camp.
Tangihua Main Ridge is a rough track, which follows the main ridge through thick vegetation. The views from the track are very rewarding on a clear day.
Explore a remarkable array of goldmining relics in Big River, one of the most intact mining areas.

Croesus Track is one of the finest surviving examples of a miners' track (1881) on the West Coast. Visitors can also experience what life was like for miners by staying in historic Croesus Top Hut, or by visiting the Garden Gully Hut.

column3: North West Circuit Stewart Island Rakiura
column37: The North West Circuit offers challenging multi-day tramping around Rakiura/Stewart island’s northern coast.
Climb to the top of Tokatoka and enjoy the stunning 360-degree views.
This easy track through native bush has creeks for kids to explore and a grassy picnic area close to the car park - it's a great option for families.
This popular short, undulating walk through grassland is surrounded by mountains and goes right round the lake.
The K2K and Orakau tracks both take you into the picturesque Kawakawa Bay; walk or ride the trails separately, or link them together for a longer day out.

column3: Lake Matheson  Te Ara Kairaumati Walk
column37: A gentle walk leads to views of the mountains reflected on the still waters of Lake Matheson. It's one of our best short walks.
You can see fine examples of toatoa (blue celery pine) and other podocarps on this short walk in Waipoua Forest.
One golden village, two tales. The picturesque preservation of two very different goldrush communities – Chinese and European – in a town that still thrives.
The walkway crosses farmland through two old pā sites with  terraces, pits and middens (shell dumps). Most of the farmland was under water prior to the Napier earthquake in 1931.
The track climbs to 521 m and offers panoramic views of the Waikanae Estuary and Kapiti Island.

column11: 10 min | 45 min | 1 hr | 3 hr one way
column37: Explore the area around Lake Heron on these tracks - discover kettle holes, and views of the lake and surrounding mountains.

column3: Twilight Beach to Te Paki Stream
column37: This 4 hour 30 minute track leads you past Scott Point to the famous 90 Mile Beach and the Te Paki sand dunes.
Take a walk through beautiful native forest dominated by matai and kahikatea as well as a large totara tree. The reserve is on a flat river terrace.
This route leads through the middle of the Urutawa Conservation Area. As it is rough and gorgy in places it is recommended for experienced trampers only.
This strenuous 4 hour track starts in the Waioeka Gorge, 23km south of Opotiki.
The Atene Skyline Track has spectacular views and a campsite for trampers wanting to stay the night.
Climb to the top of Mount Barrosa (1364 m) for good views of the surrounding countryside.
Walk or mountain bike through native forest and farmland from Opouri Saddle down to Harvey Bay (Duncan Bay).
Cross farmland and then sidle high above the picturesque Pohangina River in the Ruahine Forest Park before crossing the river and heading to the hut. Stay a night and return the same way.
This track passes through pastoral land, beech forest and sub-alpine regions, and is a great introduction to multi-night tramping.

column3: No Man s Road area tramping tracks
column37: Tracks starting at No Man's Road give access to a number of backcountry huts in the Eastern Ruahine Forest Park.
Cass - Lagoon Saddle in Craigieburn Forest Park is a two-day round trip suitable for fit, moderately experienced and equipped parties.
This quite steep and difficult tramping track leads from the Borland Road through beech forest then into the tops where you can enjoy gorgeous views of Fiordland.
Explore Mohi Bush and see if you can spot the tiny rifleman, New Zealand's smallest bird. This is one of the few places it is found outside of forest parks in Hawke's Bay.
Lake Emily gives good access to Manuka Hut, and old farm tracks to Stour Bridge car park. It's also the starting point for the section of Te Araroa through to the Rakaia River.
Enjoy spectacular views of the harbour and coastline on this short easy walk - it's suitable for children and buggies.
The day trip to Table Top is the classic climb to the tops of the western Tararua Range.
The Cascade Saddle Route is an alpine crossing between the West Matukituki and the Dart valleys in Te Wahipounamu – South West New Zealand World Heritage Area.
The Waitangitaona Wetland Walk is an easy walk through a regenerating kahikatea forest and flax wetland to a viewing platform with spectacular views of the Southern Alps, Kā Tiritiri o te Moana.

column3: Purity Kelly Knight Hut Loop Track
column37: A loop track that takes in the Pourangaki River valley and the open tops of the Hikurangi Range in the Ruahine Forest Park.
Walk to the spectacular Putangirua Pinnacles or further for excellent views of Palliser Bay and Lake Onoke - the shorter options are suitable for kids.

column3: Pirongia summit via Mahaukura and Tirohanga Tracks
column37: Choose a there-and-back track to the summit of Mount Pirongia, or combine the tracks for a circuit trip to Pahautea Hut.
This bush walk at Mimiwhangata offers superb views of Mimiwhangata, the coast and the Poor Knights Islands:
At the end of Harwoods Hole Track is Harwoods Hole, the deepest vertical shaft in New Zealand. Find out how to get there and important safety information.

The track was developed with wheelbarrows, picks and shovels as early as 1910. Both ends of the track pass through some 3 km of farmland before entering the forest, which contains good stands of tawa, kamahi and rimu.
Explore the Nina Valley on these tracks - the track to Nina Hut is suitable for families with children who have some tramping experience and new trampers.
This 10 minute walk begins beside one lake and heads gently down to the other.
Nelson Creek is an excellent spot to go walking, camping and exploring. With historic water races, tunnels, recreational gold fossicking and a number of short walks, there is plenty to do.
Dry Creek Track provides great backcountry opportunities for short walks, tramping and mountain biking with access to the Dry Creek and Neinei i Kura Conservation areas.
Walnut Track in the Puketi Forest is a steep ridge track through beautiful kauri forest. The track is recommended for experienced and well-equipped trampers.
The 2 hour return walk to Onepoto Caves branches off to various caves in the area. The track then descends into a small valley where you’ll find the largest number of caves on the walk.
The Wether Range tracks are found south of Omarama.
This track leads from Wainuiomata to the Orongorongo River and offers views of the Remutaka Range and surrounding areas.

column3: Rotary Ride and Waikato River Track
column37: These two tracks along the banks of the Waikato River allow for stunning views of the river, and access to Huka Falls and the network of mountain bike trails in the area.
There are two main walks at Lake Tutira, a short walk along the edge of the lake or a longer loop through the reserve.
Highly visible over a large area of the surrounding landscape the Grandview Ridge provides a spectacular vantage point for views over the upper Clutha Valley and peaks beyond.
Wander through beech forest and along the sandy foreshore of Milford Sound, and enjoy fabulous views of Mitre Peak - it's an easy, short walk that's great for kids.

column11: 5 min one way | 10 min one way
column37: Walk to the one of the world's oldest continuously operating generators or to Dawson Falls (18 m).
On the Whirinaki Waterfall Loop Track you'll follow the Whirinaki River as it flows through podocarp forest.
Walk up to a viewing platform for extensive views of the surrounding area.

column3: Comet Road end to Shutes Hut
column37: From Comet Road End take a 2-3 hour walk to historic Shutes Hut, built in 1920 for rabbiters and musterers to use.
Walk 5 minutes from the carpark to Allans Beach and see sea lions and penguins.

Take a scenic walk along the banks of the Waikato River, or simply explore the many lookout points at Huka Falls, one of the most visited natural attractions in New Zealand - these short, easy walks are great for kids.
This route traverses rugged river valleys and crosses two alpine saddles. The alpine sections demand experience and good route finding skills in other than fine weather conditions.
This is a pleasant, short walking track in Hope Arm on Lake Manapouri, leading to either West Beach or the waterfalls above the cove.
The Loop Walk around the headland provides a little of everything that Mimiwhangata has to offer.
Visit Long Beach on this family and dog friendly walk and have a picnic at the reserve.
These easy walks are great for kids - there's a campground and hut nearby to stay at too.
Get panoramic views of Wainuiomata and the Hutt Valley as you climb to the top of Mt McKerrow.
This route takes you through spectacular rock-fall, past mountain tarns and over two alpine passes.
These tracks are found within a few kilometres of Twizel.
This easy track is just 1 km north of Maiki/Flagstaff Hill, near Russell.  Tapeka Point is the perfect base for exploring this part of the Bay of Islands by land or water.
Pataua Island Track is a short access track that skirts the Pataua Estuary and leads you to a lovely beach.
Walk or cycle along the banks of the Clutha River near Lake Wanaka.
The Cloudy Peak Track from its 1526 m high point, provides fantastic views of the Upper Clutha plains and peaks of the Lindis and St Bathans ranges.
This is a fabulous, easy day walk on the Routeburn Track (a Great Walk), leading to the beautiful Earland Falls with plenty of mountain and valley views along the way.
The Travers-Sabine Circuit is a medium to hard tramp traversing 80 km of river valleys and an alpine pass in Nelson Lakes National Park.

column3: Anatoki and Historic Kill Devil Pack Tracks
column37: Explore beautiful beech forest, dramatic gorge scenery and rock debris dam at Lake Stanley. Trampers can also enjoy a historic hut experience in restored character huts from 1930s gold mining days.

column3: Te Ara a Waiau Walkway Cycleway
column37: Walk or cycle through bush from Franz Josef township to the Franz Josef Glacier car park.
Take a strenuous day hike and enjoy the spectacular scenery from the tops of the Ngamoko Range in the Ruahine Forest Park.
From Cape Reinga/Te Rerenga Wairua, this 2 km track follows the West Coast leading you down past steep cliffs to the long, sweeping Te Werahi Beach.
Follow the gentle incline of an old coach road up the valley and onto the Mataraua Forest plateau.
DOC manages a number of short walks starting from the Stony Batter Historic Reserve.
Explore Rangitoto Island Scenic Reserve on these longer walks. Walk around the coast of Rangitoto, to adjoining Motutapu Island, or continue on from the summit to Islington Bay.
Scenic tramps that offer views of Mount Taranaki and down across the Taranaki Ring Plain to the coast.
A good zigzag track and marked route climbs to the bushline on Mt Alfred. There is no public access to the summit.
An easy climb through pōhutukawa forest and lava fields gives way to panoramic views of Auckland and the Hauraki Gulf from the summit of this volcanic island. This is one of our best shorts.
This track offers views of the surrounding countryside and evidence of the logging era.
This difficult tramping track leads from the Milford Road up the Boyd Creek onto the tops of the Countess Range, in the Snowdon Forest area.
This short walk leads to a viewing platform over a lagoon, where tall trees are reflected in the water.
A steep climb through red beech eases before reaching picturesque Lake Rere, a popular tourist destination in the late 19th century.
The Wanganui River valley provides rugged backcountry opportunities for those with suitable skills and experience.
A gentle 30 min walk through bush and over farmland to the beautiful Omaru Falls. On Omaru Road, clearly signposted from SH4.
Walk around Lake Rotoiti surrounded by high mountain peaks – with the option to catch a water taxi one way or to stay overnight in a hut, it's a great option for families with children.
This challenging tramping route leads up the Tutoko river valley through beech forest and open flats under impressive Fiordland mountain peaks.
North Block Road is the most popular starting point for visitors to Eastern Ruahine Forest Park. From there tramping tracks take you to Smith’s Stream Hut and Waipawa Forks Hut.
Walk through a nikau grove and podocarp/broadleaf forest.
Take a self-guided loop walk around Sutton Salt Lake, New Zealand's only inland salt lake.
These tracks can be reached on foot from Lake Tekapo township.

column3: Coromandel Walkway and mountain bike track
column37: Walk or mountain bike between Fletcher Bay and Stony Bay.
This very challenging tramping route goes from Lake Te Anau across to George Sound, Fiordland.
Retrace the miners’ daily walk from their homes in Skippers to the Crystal Mine, their workplace in the 1930s and 40s.
Large podocarps and a chance to hear kaka and other native birdlife while walking along the Mokaihaha Track which takes you past Lake Rotohokahoka.

column3: Bob s Cove Track & Nature Walk
column37: This short walk passes through native bush to reach a stunning cove on Lake Wakatipu - it's a great option for kids.
Walk through an outstanding example of a subtropical rain forest past a scenic waterfall on this well-graded short walk - with a sheltered picnic at the car park it's great option for families.
Zigzag up to a high country lake that is a popular fishing spot for trout.
This walk passes through native forest and bush, crossing burns (streams) and giving access to Lake Wanaka itself. This track is suitable for walking, mountain biking and horse riding.
Walk through forest to the centre of Matiu/Somes Island, on one of the original tracks on the island.
See steaming hot mineral pools and spluttering mud pools on this short, easy walk - it's a good option for children but be sure to supervise them.
For young families or riders with insufficient time or experience to attempt the full St James Cycle Trail, the Homestead Run will give you a taste of St James.

Wind across the lower slopes of the Mt Taranaki - discover towering cliffs, a mighty waterfall, a sphagnum moss swamp and stunning views on this day walk version of the popular 2–3 day Pouakai Circuit.
This track gives outstanding views of the Remutaka Range and Orongorongo Valley.
This walkway uses the Kapuni to Auckland gas pipeline route for a considerable distance.  The laying of the pipeline opened up walking access to the dramatic forest and coastal country of the region.
Grass clearings and an old fence are a legacy of days gone by when this section was highly modified by burning and farming.
The Shotover Saddle Route offers magnificent views of the West Matukituki and Rob Roy valleys.
Cross the Aorangi Range from Putangirua Pinnacles to Cape Palliser.

These tracks follow the upper reaches of the Wilkin Valley and can be treated as a separate tramping trip or connect with, say, the Gillespie Circuit. It can also lead to a route to the Matukituki Valley.
Climb up to Panekire Bluffs for magnificant views of Lake Waikaremoana and the surrounding mountains.
An ideal family walk through nikau and tawa forest.
Walk from Gore Bay through a scenic reserve to a lookout with views of Pegasus Bay.

column3: Historic Haast to Paringa Cattle Track
column37: This track was built in 1875 by farmers at Haast. Stock were driven from the Landsborough and Cascade valleys to sale yards at Whataroa, a two-week journey at best. It’s now a three-day tramp.
This track takes you to a viewpoint over historic Te Aumiti/French Pass, where the tide rushes back and forth like a river.
The classic Mt Holdsworth - Jumbo Circuit is a two to three day tramp involving a climb through beech-podocarp forest to some of the best alpine tops travel in the Tararua Forest Park.
Honeycomb Rock is a spectacular outcrop on the Wairarapa coast, so named because of the cell-like weathering pattern which gives the rock a honeycomb appearance.
Explore Takitimu Mountains on these tracks and routes.
Follow the bank of the Kerikeri River through regenerating forest and discover the remains of an historic power house, and Wharepuke and Rainbow Falls - it's a great option for walking children.
The 3-hour return walk along the Peach Cove Track requires skill and a reasonable level of fitness. The track has several steep climbs before it drops down to Peach Cove’s sandy beach.

Mount Adams sits proudly on the edge of the Adams Wilderness Area in the Southern Alps/Kā Tiritiri o te Moana, and is a focal point for travellers along State Highway 6 from Lake Ianthe to Lake Wahapo.
The Hollyford Track is a fantastic 4-8 day Fiordland tramp from the mountains to the sea at Martins Bay, and can be walked all year round.
Burrill Route was formed in the 1970s by miners prospecting for copper.
Take a quick walk to a long, white sandy beach on Northland's Karikari Peninsula.
There are numerous options, some suitable for children, for a loop walk from Wooded Gully picnic area.

This excellent circuit for experienced parties provides spectacular mountain scenery, alpine vegetation and river valleys filled with silver beech/tawhai.  The side trip to Crucible Lake is exceptional.
Walk to a picturesque, 18 m waterfall or through goblin forest to lava-formed pools that are good for a dip - these tracks are suitable for children and have plenty to keep them interested.
Superb 360 degree views and impressive limestone bluffs are features of this walk.
Explore the old Leyland O’Brien tramline besides the headwaters of the Ngamuwahine River.
Two loop tracks and a wonderful viewing hide have been built so you get up close and personal with the wetland.

This well-graded track is a great overnight tramp for families with children and new trampers - it passes through changing forest types to the open tops, with great views of the Hawke’s Bay plains and excellent sunrises from the hut.
For amazing views of the countryside and coastline, follow this track along the ridgeline of the Brynderwyn range.

The whole 44 km-long walkway and cycleway runs from Hornby (Ōtautahi/Christchurch) to Little River on Banks Peninsula. Easy grades makes this walk or ride suitable for young children and family groups.
This scenic track follows the rugged coastline of Cape Reinga and descends to Te Werahi and Twilight beaches. Self-sufficient camping is available.
Enjoy a short walk alongside Woolshed Creek.
A steady climb through regenerating native bush to the summit of Mount Manaia rewards you with breathtaking views of the dramatic entrance to Whangarei Harbour.

Experience the spectacular Marlborough Sounds whilst walking or biking the Queen Charlotte Track. The track stretches 70 km from historic Meretoto/Ship Cove through to Anakiwa in the Grove Arm of Queen Charlotte Sound.
This track starts from a historic 'Howe truss' bridge and has excellent waterfall and forest views.
This well-graded track to the tussock tops on Whanahuia Range is a great overnight tramp for families with children and new trampers.
Walk alongside the Awakino River to Leitch's Hut.
This route for intrepid trampers is the longest track to Leitch's Hut.

A variety of operators offer guided walks along the spectacular Queen Charlotte Track in the heart of the Marlborough Sounds. Relax in comfortable accommodation showcasing the gourmet cuisine that the region is renowed for.
Enjoy an easy walk with the family around Lake Ngatu - a freshwater dune lake and recreation reserve. The lake is popular with water sport enthusiasts, day visitors, and locals.

This track passes through coastal forest, pine-clad valleys and dense native bush - with a fairly easy grade it's suitable for children, although some climbing is required and there are a few steep places.
The Waitomo Walkway traverses classic limestone landscape, meanders beside the Waitomo Stream through forest and open farmland.

column3: Fox Glacier  Te Ara o Tuawe Valley Walk
column37: Get spectacular views of Fox Glacier/Te Moeke o Tuawe on one of our best short walks. It's suitable for children - and they can earn a Kiwi Guardians medal too!
Explore the fascinating and family-friendly historic Brunner Mine and enjoy the interactive displays.
This steep tramping track climbs from the edge of Lake Hauroko to a lookout with great views over the lake and nearby mountain ranges.
Karioi is an ancient volcano and the views from the summit  are spectacular.
The two possible routes on this Castlepoint walk offer spectacular views as you climb above the lagoon to the base of Castle Rock - it's suitable for children.

column3: Woodside Glen and Maungatua summit walks
column11: 2 hr 30 min or 8 hr 30 min return
column37: You can walk from Outram and across Lee Creek, or for a more challenging walk follow the tramping track to the Maungatua (Maukaatua) summit.
This vanished landscape is New Zealand’s own wild west: The Bannockburn Sluicings are the scarred landscapes of a short-lived goldmining era.

column11: 5 hr 30 min  - 6 hr 30 min one way
column37: Liverpool Track is in the Matukituki Valley, an hour’s drive west from Wanaka. The track starts at Aspiring Hut which you get to on the West Matukituki Track.
This short, easy forest walk leads to four tall kauri trees growing extremely close together - it's a good option with children.
The walk to Aspiring Hut, with views up and down the West Matukituki Valley, is a great overnight tramp for families with children. It leads onto French Ridge and Liverpool Hut tracks.
This difficult tramping track leads from the Milford Road and up the Hut Creek Valley through beech forest to the river flats.
The giant kauri in the Omahuta Kauri Sanctuary were protected from logging in 1951. This short loop track leads you through a stand of mature kauri.
This short, easy walk suitable for buggies, leads to the stunning Rainbow Falls on the Kerikeri River.
These tracks provide access to Mt Richmond (1760 m) and can be combined for weekend round trip.
Walk around Huriawa Peninsula on a well-formed track suitable for children - take in spectacular views and read plaques with the history of the area. Kids can earn a Kiwi Guardians medal here too.
This circular walk passes through regenerating forest with some large tōtara, kahikatea and mataī.
Kānuka Loop Track is the only DOC-managed bush walk in Central Otago.

column3: Farewell Spit and Puponga Farm Park tracks
column37: Choose from shorter walks good for children or longer walks across farmland - discover a lighthouse and a spectacular rugged coastline.
Walk through mixed tawhai/podocarp forest on this short, easy walk - with a picnic area nearby this is a good option for children.
Penetrate deep into the wilderness of the Whanganui National Park on old Maori trail and settlers’ dray road. Shorter day and overnight opportunities are also available.

column11: 1 hr 30 min one way to summit or 3 hr 30 min one w
column37: Tramp up to the summit of Mt Tamahunga through regenerating native forest. This track is part of Te Araroa - The Long Pathway.

column3: Lewis Pass Waiau Pass Blue Lake Route
column37: Waiau Pass is an alpine crossing suitable for experienced parties only, linking Lewis Pass and Nelson Lakes National Park.
Walk to the beautiful basin that holds Lake Peel.
The Whangaruru North Head Walking Tracks can be accessed from the popular campsite at Puriri Bay. The tracks follow through native forest and ridgelines before dropping down into secluded bays.
This family friendly nature walk winds through native forest and takes just over an hour one way.
Climb up to 309 m for views of Whangaparapara harbour.
Take the shortest route to Leitch's clearing and Leitch's Hut.
From the Cameron carpark you can walk to Kuripapaango Trig or Cameron Hut. Tramps to Kiwi Saddle, Kaweka Range, Kiwi Mouth Hut and Back Ridge are also available.
See a variety of native birds on the walks on this pest-free island, as well as views of the surrounding islands.
These tracks all start from Kaiaraara Hut, a short distance from the end of Kaiaraara Bay Road, near Port FitzRoy.
Read about the gold mining history of the area at the carpark then walk to a pleasant picnic spot.
Hope valley in Lake Sumner Forest Park is accessed at Windy Point, beside SH 7, about 160 km from Christchurch.
This 9 km walk between Pandora and Tapotupotu Bay mainly follows old farm tracks until you reach idyllic Tapotupotu Bay.
The steep climb to Camp Stream Hut is part of Te Araroa  Trail and is popular with people walking the trail over summer and with ski tourers over winter.
The Manuoha-Waikareiti Track is a spectacular and challenging walk suited to reasonably experienced trampers. The 32 km walk takes a minimum of three days to complete.
Walk around spectacular limestone formations - this is a good option for kids with open grassland for exploring as well.
Explore the beech forest and water races right next to the site of New Zealand’s first goldrush and discover historic dams that powered the shifting of entire hills.
The 39 m Waitonga Falls is Tongariro National Park’s highest waterfall. The well-formed track passes through mountain beech and kaikawaka forest.
Follows the Waiohine and Tauherenikau Rivers for 36 km between Holdsworth and Kaitoke. A good introductory track for people new to the Tararuas.

column3: Emily Falls and Rata Falls Tracks
column11: 45 min one way | 1 hr one way
column37: Choose between these two waterfall walks.
Enjoy the views from the summit of Mount William, just south of the Bombay Hills.
The short walk for the whole family provides views of the threatened native mistletoe.

column11: 7-9 hr to lake, 9-11 hr to bivvy rock
column37: This challenging tramping route leads up the Moraine Creek from the Hollyford Road to beautiful Lake Adelaide in an impressive glacial basin.
This pleasant, short walking track leads through beech forest to a lookout at Lake Monowai, Fiordland.
This short walk through beautiful forest has information panels about plant and birds along the way - it's a great option for children.
Explore the wild and remote environment of the Denniston Plateau. The historic sites provide a glimpse of times gone by.
This walking track crosses the historic Tauranga Bridge and passes alongside the Tauranga Stream.
This walkway offers several geological and historic features as it traverses the edge of the Rakaia Gorge.
Hopkins valley, in Ruataniwha Conservation Park, is near Lake Ohau.

column3: Waiau Falls and Kauri Grove Lookout Walk
column37: Visit a popular swimming hole at Waiau Falls and view a mature kauri grove on this walk.
Follow an old logging road over inland ridges through the Kaiikanui Forest.
A 30 minute walk in the Twin Kauri Scenic Reserve takes you by groves of tree fern and kauri.
Climb through native bush with views of Otago Harbour and Otago Peninsula.
This track was made around 1910 by road workers using wheelbarrows, picks and shovels.
This is a steep tramp to the open tussock peak of Mt. Tuhua (1125 m) and is suitable for fit people only.
This flat loop track, ideal for kids, follows the lagoon shoreline with good bird watching to the rusting remains of the Waverley ship.

column3: Pelorus Bridge Scenic Reserve walking tracks
column37: Enjoy beautiful forest and river scenery on one of several walks - there are short, easy options for kids and a river for them to swim in too.

column3: Gray s Bush Scenic Reserve walks
column37: These walks pass through a remnant of the tall kahikatea (podocarp) forest which once covered much of the Gisborne plains - the shorter option is suitable for buggies and wheelchairs.
The track travels the length of the peninsula, mainly along the ridgetop, giving access to the many sheltered bays and providing outstanding coastal views.
Enjoy regenerating shrubland, coastal views and kohekohe forest on these walks that are suitable for children.
The Whakapono and Tumanako tracks form a loop.  Plan for the walk to take about 2-3 hours if you wish to complete the full loop.
A track climbing through beech forest following the Shirt Tail Stream in Kingston.
Follow an old tramline (1898 - 1928) on a relatively flat track through the spectacular Waitawheta Gorge - with interpretation panels as well, it's a great option for kids.
Walk alongside the attractive Waikuku Stream then climb up to good views of the surrounding countryside.
The Moonlight Pack Track offers the opportunity to see reminders of the gold mining history of the area, and to walk through West Coast native beech forest.
This track begins on the Kiko Loop and continues as far as the park boundary on the slopes of Mt Ngapuketurua.
This very popular loop walk offers excellent 360-degree views – it's close to Wanaka and suitable for all ages and abilities.
This short walk boasts beautiful scenery and spectacular mining remnants including disused gold mining tunnels - kids will love it!

Explore the remote bush, cliffs and waterfalls of the Western Bays of Lake Taupo. Normally accessible only by boat, these trails take you through a variety of landscapes with fantastic lookout points.
This family-friendly track starts near Taieri Mouth.
Located beyond Port Jackson campsite, this stunning coastal walk leaves the Muriwai Hilltop car park and heads along a benched farm track along the ridge  towards Wharekaiatua Pa.
An easy loop trail with interpretation panels provide a 1 hour walking experience in the Waimana Valley at the north end of Te Urewera.
At Glacier Burn you'll climb through beech forest to Glacier Basin. Follow the creek beyond to view the Humboldt Mountains.
Walk or mountain bike through the Kaimanawa Forest Park taking in two spectacular gorges, and the characteristic beech and kamahi forest.
Explore old moraine surfaces on this easy, short walk, south of Fox Glacier township.
Walk to Sandymount via the Chasm and Lovers Leap and get spectacular views of the coastline.

column3: Windy Canyon and Palmer s Track to Mt Hobson (Hirakimata)
column37: Windy Canyon is a popular walk on Great Barrier Island, offering spectacular views. You can then continue on Palmers Track to the summit of Mt Hobson (Hirakimata).

column3: Mount Messenger to Whitecliffs Walkway Track
column37: This track climbs to the summit of Mt Messenger and then descends to the coast.
The 27-km Nydia Track in the Sounds area of Marlborough is an easy 2-day tramp. Plan on an overnight stop at Nydia Bay.

A loop track around Matiu/Somes Island offers 360 degree views of Wellington harbour - with native wildlife, remnants from the world wars, historic quarantine buildings, and a lighthouse, there is plenty to keep kids interested.
This moderately challenging track leads into the beautiful and rugged Waima Forest.
These well-formed tracks lead into Oteake Conservation Park.

column3: Cave Stream Scenic Reserve tracks and cave walk
column37: Two short walks lead to the cave entrances – you can can also walk through the cave passage which meanders and twists in pitch darkness for 594 m between the two entrances.
The Sanctuary Track in Whirinaki Te Pua-a-Tāne Conservation Park is an easy loop track that leads through remnant podocarp forest.
Climb to the open tops with superb views and picturesque tarns.
The Pukekohe Stream Track offers visitors the opportunity to view a regenerating kauri forest. A side track leads to an unusual stand of kauri and hard beech.
Traverse rugged Skippers Creek to see New Zealand’s first industrial hydro power scheme or take the trail to the heart of Skippers’ quartz reef mining history.
From the mouth of the Albert Burn follow the farmed river flats into the gorge and on to the Albert Burn Hut.
Enjoy the views of the Pohangina Valley from the end of No.1 Line or shorter Trig Loop Track.
Walk or mountain bike this track to Isthmus Peak (1385 m) and cross the undulating skyline ridge.

Several tracks start from Hurunui swingbridge at the end of Lake Sumner Road, which is a 4WD track from Loch Katrine onwards. Vehicle access through a locked gate requires getting permission from Lakes Station.

column11: 4 hr to bush edge, 6 - 8 hr to rock bivvy
column37: A challenging tramping route from the Milford Road into the Falls Creek valley, surrounded by impressive Fiordland mountains.

Avalanche Peak is the only peak in Arthur's Pass that is marked by a poled route to the summit. The climb is 1,100 m vertical from the village (over just 2.5 km horizontal), and on a fine day, you will be rewarded with grand views of the surrounding peaks
There is a diverse range of tracks within a short distance of Twizel.
From a 10 minute jaunt to a swimming beach to hour long round trips, the walking tracks of Queen Charlotte Sound give you a range of options.
This walking track is a beautiful cool, retreat during the summer months.
Mangaone Walkway follows an old bush tramway in low hill country east of Waikanae. It was historically known as Reikorangi Track.
A short track follows a loop that takes in some peaceful forest glades in among lush regeneration beneath stately palms.
This tramping track travels through the cloud forest above the Leith Saddle on Dunedin's Northern Motorway.
This public access route travels along Birch Creek in the Ahuriri valley.
Walking the track will take you through a mixed landscape of pasture and wooded areas to the beautiful white sands of Taronui Bay.

column3: Mount Damper to Te Rerepahupahu Falls track
column37: This track to Te Rerepahupahu Falls is recommended for fit and experienced trampers only.
This track passes through a fine example of lowland forest, one of the few areas left unlogged on the Mamaku Plateau.
On Bob's Cove Bridle Track you'll follow history along the original bridle track that linked Queenstown and Glenorchy.

column3: Boyd Oamaru and Cascade Hut tracks
column37: Combine these tracks for a multi-night tramp with lush beech forest, river crossings and wildlife. Several huts and road ends allow you to tailor a trip to suit.
This easy, peaceful walking track lingers beside a small fresh water stream.
This historic trail follows an old bridle path that transported coal to the gold mining dredges 1890s-1930s.

column11: 6 hr going south, 7 hr going north
column37: Burtton's Track (Scotts Road to Mangahao Road) lies between Palmerston North and Shannon.
Waterfalls, lakeside picnics and the tree fuschia await on the walking tracks of Lake Rotoroa in Nelson Lakes National Park.

The Round the Mountain Track showcases the varied volcanic landscapes and alpine vegetation on the flanks of the active volcano Mount Ruapehu. It's a more remote alternative to the Tongariro Northern Circuit Great Walk.
View the second largest living kauri in New Zealand, Te Matua Ngahere - it's a good option for kids.
This provides access to one of the Hāwea Conservation Park's most beautiful areas, the Hunter Valley.
Walk to Mapoutahi Pā along a sandy beach in Purakaunui Bay.
Climb to the summit of Mt Oxford (1364 m) for good views of the Canterbury Plains and into Lees Valley.
This tramping track in Deep Cove, Doubtful Sound leads around the cove to a stream looking up to Helena Falls.
Three walks on and around the very scenic Tautuku Bay.
Climb to the summit of Mt Richardson (1047 m) for great views to the Puketeraki Range and over Lees Valley.
Follow the Okuku River to Pinchgut Hut.
The Washbourn Scenic Reserve is a delightful patch of forest, providing a very easy 15-minute walk.
This route winds along Pudding Hill Stream through Mount Hutt Forest.
This walk follows a branch of the tramline through the bush to the North South track, and returns along a separate tramline branch back to the road.
Enjoy the coastal views on this walkway between Rotokura/Cable Bay and The Glen, near Nelson. Boating, sea kayaking, and snorkeling are all possible.
This track is closed until at least December 2018 due to safety hazards.
It’s a 4-hour climb to the top of Alex Knob. The track zigzags up to Rata Lookout for a view of the Franz Josef Glacier. From there follow the marked track to the summit.
Experienced trampers can walk to the 4-bunk Makarora Hut, taking in the Stewart Falls along the way.
The Aotea Track offers a range of spectacular landscapes, superb views and rich history.

Situated at the base of the Coromandel Range, the Karangahake Gorge Historic Walkway follows the old railway line between Paeroa and Waihi, giving access to impressive remains from the mining and railway eras.
From Kaweka Road you can access Makahu Saddle via Whittle Road. The saddle is a popular starting point for walks into the mountain tops.
Follow a stream through beautiful native forest or walk through a 20 metre limestone cave - with swimming and picnicking opportunities as well, these tracks are great for children.
Blessed with a mild climate, golden beaches and lush coastal native bush, the Abel Tasman Coast Track has it all.
A pleasant climb up an old musterers' track above an upland river gorge.
This marked route links Charlies Saddle to Stanley Vale Hut in the St James Conservation Area.

A short walk through lush native bush leads to the cascading Wainui Falls, the largest and most accessible falls in Golden Bay/Mohua - there's a long swing bridge for children to enjoy as well. It's one of our best short walks.

column11: 3 hr 45 min to junction one way from car park
column37: The Te Haua Uru Track is located in the Tangihua Forest and links with the Horokaka Track and Tangihua Main Ridge Track to form a loop that will take experienced trampers 9 hours to complete.
This short, easy track loops around a wetland - with interpretation panels as well it's a great option for kids.
From the top of Knuckle Hill are excellent views of the top of the South Island, particularly Farewell Spit and Whanganui Inlet.
See the Tarawera River disappearing underground at various sites before it re-emerges through the spectacular Tarawera Falls through narrow fissures in a fractured rhyolite lava cliff.
This return walk traverses the coast part way to Cape Rodney. overlooking New Zealand's oldest and most popular marine reserve.
Pass through farmland and manuka scrubland to Maitai Bay Headlands, where you can enjoy scenic views of Waikato Bay and Maitai Bay.
This pleasant and easy walk takes you around the coastline across a causeway to Motukiore Island, and is a great summer family outing.
Walk or ride over the headland between Whakaipo and Whangamata bays and enjoy the lake views and native bush.
Goldie Bush Scenic Reserve offers a variety of walks through coastal kauri forest, taking in the impressive Mokoroa Falls.

column11: 2 hr 30 min for complete island circuit
column37:
Explore historic sites such as the ships' graveyard and the quarantine barracks, as well as swimming and waterskiing beaches and a bird-watching barricade.
The easy grade makes these walks suitable for small children and family groups.
The round-trip walk is 16 km in length and takes between 4 hours 30 minutes to 5 hours to complete. The track crosses farmlands and dunes.
The Manuka Bay track links Port Robinson with the mouth of the Hurunui River. Passing through a variety of coastal scenery, this easy tramping grade track is ideal for family groups.
This loop track around the northern face of Pourangahau/Mount Robert offers spectacular views over Lake Rotoiti that will keep even kids entertained. It can be enjoyed as a day or overnight walk.
Feel the full force and sound of fresh mountain water falling 131 m down one of New Zealand’s most stunning waterfalls. It's one of our best short walks.
Harper Pass was the main pathway to and from the west coast for Māori when trading for pounamu (greenstone). Follow this historic route from west to east.
This is a multi-day tramp using rugged, unmarked routes suitable for expert backcountry trampers only. Trampers will need to camp in addition to staying in huts.
For an easy overnight tramp, great for kids, walk to Speargrass Hut on this well graded track.

The Moerangi Track is a 35 km dual purpose track, which attracts both mountain bikers and trampers to experience a multi-day adventure deep in the wonderful 'Jurassic' Whirinaki Te Pua-a-Tāne Conservation Park.
Walk to a cave entrance with a viewing platform.
Go for an easy forest and beach walk to Whangamumu Harbour and Te Toroa Bay. Learn about the history while challenging the kids.
This easy track passes through superb groves of mature hard beech in the lower reaches of Graces Stream.
Discover a forested gorge, natural sculpted cliffs and low limestone arches on this spectacular loop walk - plenty to keep kids interested.
Stunning views of the Coromandel coast guide you to the dramatic cliffs and iconic rock archway of Cathedral Cove. This is one of best short walks.
Walk this track as part of a day walk circuit from Flora car park.
Climb to a lookout on Mount Pirongia with excellent views across the Waikato Basin to the Kaimai Ranges.
Climb one of the most popular peaks in Canterbury for magnificent views to Mt Somers, Mt Hutt and across the plains to the coast.
Enjoy a short walk through native forest rich in kahikatea, totara, beech, matai, tawa and kowhai. Plenty of native birds to see as well.
Walk along the tussock tops of the Hikurangi Range between Purity and McKinnon huts in the Ruahine Forest Park.
Walk through bush and along the beach to explore the impressive Cathedral Caves.
Walk around the Orokonui lagoon through native bush and view the natural wetland providing habitat for native fish and foraging birds.

The track to Donnelly Flat passes through some of the best mixed podocarp/broadleaf forest in the Tararua Range - this short, easy walk with a picnic area and stream on route is an great option for kids.
Discover river sculpted caves or great views out to sea, as well as see and hear many of New Zealand's bush birds, on these tracks from Trotters Gorge Campsite.
These tracks can be combined to form a circuit walk to Tarn Hut.
Walk to this lookout point on Mount Pirongia for one of the best vantage points over the west coast harbours.
Climb a short track to marvel at an unusual square trunked kauri and enjoy the view across to Maumaupaki on the main Coromandel Range.
Follow old milling trails through the bush.
Pukeatua Track connects Otaki Forks to Waikanae.
Enjoy stunning views of Lake Tekapo while walking or riding this track.
The Te Kere Haka Track follows the shore of Lake Wakatipu.
Enjoy listening to and spotting birds on walks in two areas of Kapiti Island.
This route is a classic traverse of the Southern Alps, crossing over Goat Pass.
The track to Kelly Knight Hut crosses farmland to the Ruahine Forest Park boundary, then sidles above the Pourangaki River to reach the hut via a swingbridge. Stay a night and return the same way.
This coastal walk takes you through the Matietie Historic Reserve.
A loop track follows through the bush and up to the summit, with a lookout tower and great views across to the Kaimai Ranges and Firth of Thames.
This easy walk winds through native bush along the lake edge, offering fantastic views and great picnic, swimming and fishing spots. It's perfect for families and those wanting to enjoy Lake Taupo.
Built in 1878, this rail route between the Hutt Valley and Featherston is now a gently graded 18 km walk, run or mountain bike ride, with opportunities for camping, swimming and fishing.

column11: 4 - 6 days round trip from Freshwater landing
column37: Stewart Island/Rakiura's Southern Circuit Track is a remote, challenging tramp and requires good fitness, route-finding skills and backcountry experience.
Follow the Goulter River from Lake Chalice.
A good, steep bush walk to the uplands of the McKerrow Range. Great views of the Makarora Valley below and the alps beyond.
This is an easy walk to Framptons Hut and on to the Waima Main Range Track.
Walk to Curtis Falls and enjoy a dip in the shallow pool beneath the falls.
This enjoyable, short tramping track offers a superb setting and views from Mt Burns, Monowai, Fiordland.
A  transalpine route that mixes the best of east with the wilds of the west.
Weave your way through dramatic rock bluffs to the Long Gully Bluffs Conservation Area to get dramatic views of Lake Dunstan and the St Bathans Range - it's a steep but rewarding climb.
The Hapuakohe Walkway can be done as a 2-day trek, split by the Kaihere-Ohinewai Road. Smaller sections can be completed within a day. It is suitable for experienced trampers only.
There are five tramping tracks accessible from the Acheron Road; from short tracks from the cob buildings at Molesworth and Acheron to longer tracks with panorama views.

column11: 2 hr return to the bushline, 5 hr return to Sawyer
column37: The Sawyer Burn Track climbs through the forest to the bushline and has superb views of Lake Hāwea and the surrounding mountains.
The Kakepuku Track in Kakepuku Historic Reserve climbs up through bush to the summit of Kakepuku, an old volcano.
Discover wide open beaches and rocky headlands on the rugged coastline between the Hokianga Harbour and the majestic Waimamaku River.
Enjoy magnificent views over Banks Peninsula, the Canterbury plains, Southern Alps and Pacific ocean on this track, which is about an hour's drive from Christchurch.
A short easy walk to a viewpoint that overlooks the historic Oxenbridge Tunnel river diversion and an old steam engine.
The track to the summit of Parapara Peak (1249 m) is steep and difficult, and requires fitness and experience.

Scenery and history combine in this walk along an historic bush tramway, with spectacular vistas up and down the Ngakawau Gorge, alongside an unfolding view of the Mangatini Falls. Located near Westport, it's one of our best short walks.
There is a popular lookout through this track with scenic views over the northern Bay of Plenty.
Walk through a variety of attractive scenery - with picnic areas and good places to swim as well this track is a good option with children.
Explore the remnants of the old Egmont Branch railway quarry complex while walking through native forest.
The Waipapa River Track is a scenic two-day tramp that follows the Waipapa River through the heart of Puketi Forest. The tramp is only recommended for experienced and well-equipped trampers.
A visit to Gillespies Beach offers a scenic drive, lovely views of the Southern Alps Kā Tiritiri o te Moana, an historic cemetery and coastal walks.
The journey along 'Māui's fish hook' takes you to the world's largest mainland gannet colony and past rugged cliffs. It's one of our best day hikes.

column3: Waitaanga South Road to Te Rerepahupahu Falls Track
column37: Follow an historic logging tramline to Te Rerepahupahu Falls.

column3: Pirongia summit via Bell & Tahuanui Tracks
column37: Combine these tracks for an overnight circuit to Pahautea Hut and Mount Pirongia.
This easy loop track in Fiordland forest in Monowai is suitable for families.
These easements tracks provide access to the Rakaia Valley side of Hakatere Conservation Park.
The Barra Track follows the Waingawa River to Mitre Flats and Mitre Flats Hut.

column11: 3 hr 30 min - 4 hr 30 min one way
column37: Climb to the top of Mt Arthur (1795 m) for panoramic views.
Walk in the footsteps of chief Hongi Hika and early missionaries to Kororipo Pā – this short, easy walk is suitable for children.
Climb up to one of the best views from Mount Pirongia of Hamilton and Te Awamutu.
Lake Surprise and Old Blyth tramping tracks are 5 hour return hikes you can enjoy in the Ohakune area.
The open summit of Kapakapanui is one of the best viewpoints in the Tararua Range.
This area was extensively altered by the 1886 Tarawera eruption and the landscape is being slowly regenerated by native plant species.
Climb to the centre of the island for spectacular 360-degree views of the surrounding Bay of Islands.
Walk up to Sylvester Hut as day walk or overnight tramp with children - enjoy great views from the hut and explore a series of lakes on the open tops behind the hut.
Vast tussock-covered ridgelines and spectacular alpine vistas contrast with peaceful lakeside and valley beech forest in this wilderness adventure.
The Huxley valley branches off Hopkins valley in Ruataniwha Conservation Park.
Horokaka Track is a challenging track that includes strenuous climbing. The track leads up to an old logging road and then follows the ridge to the Horokaka Transmitter.
Walk to the remains of the old kauri dam, and up to the summit of Mt Hobson (Hirakimata) for a 360-degree panorama.
This track is for experienced trampers. It first climbs over a saddle to an old farm road and then descends through regenerating forest to Wairakau Stream. It ends at Lane Cove Hut.
This circuit offers fantastic views of Mt Taranaki from the Maketawa Hut - it can be enjoyed as a half day tramp but is also a good overnight tramp for families with children and new trampers.
A range of tracks for walkers and mountain bikers alike, in an attractive, upland valley. Easily accessed off SH8 between Tarras and Omarama.

column3: Matiu Somes Island gun emplacements track
column37: Walk to the top of Matiu/Somes Island, to see gun emplacements built during World War II and enjoy 360 degree views.
The track to Waitewaewae Hut crosses a terrace above the Otaki River, before entering the bush to follow an old tramway and criss-cross several creeks.
A pleasant walking track alongside the river through beech forest, along part of the Kepler Track (Great Walk) near Te Anau.
Two family friendly short walks starting from Urchin Campsite at the end of Kaimanawa Road.
An excellent but strenuous trip in the remote north western Ruahine Forest Park renowned for its scenery and ecological values. Fly in by helicopter and walk out.
Enjoy views of the Kaikoura coastline.
This tramping track has some steep sections, but the wildlife and vegetation makes the effort worthwhile.
The Pakihi Track is a stunning 20 km journey through lush Eastland forest.
This short walk takes in the Whangamarino Redoubt and Te Teoteo's Pā - two key sites of conflict during the Waikato War of 1863-64.
Evidence of the past can be savoured today as trampers walk through the Eliza Mine Loop Track.
The Arahura and Styx valleys are popular areas for tramping and hunting. The main access in both valleys is via benched formations constructed during the early gold mining days.
Enjoy expansive views out across the Canterbury Plain along an marked route up into The Hunters Hills.
This short loop track is a great way for walkers and mountain bikers to experience the variety of nature in the Kaimanawa Forest Park.
Experience the best of Arthur’s Pass's diverse alpine vegetation, waterfalls, wetlands, rich history and stunning mountain views on this walk.

Experience 'the finest walk in the world' as you retrace the steps of early explorers on the world-renowed Milford Track. Take a journey along valleys carved by glaciers, wander through ancient rainforests and admire cascading waterfalls.
This short walk leads to an historic fire tower with views over the forest - it's a great option for kids.
The Antimony Mines Track which leads from Endeavour Inlet past the site of an old mine and on to the Titirangi Road.

These two scenic tracks offer excellent opportunity for trout fishing and hunting.  The Nikau Flat Track follows alongside the Waioeka River and the Kotepato Track follows alongside the Te Pato Stream.
This is a short but challenging tramping track from Hope Arm in Lake Manapouri up to the summit of The Monument, with great lake views in good weather.
Discover towering kahikatea on this short loop walk.
A demanding track suitable for fit walkers. The tramp will take you 2 hours and leads between the Nikau Loop and Mangakawa tracks.
Climb to the summit of Mount Somers for 360 degrees views.
You can get to Wharite Peak Track and Coppermine Track from Coppermine Road End in  Eastern Ruahine Forest Park.
This route takes you from the open east-coast river flats over a rugged, untracked alpine pass into the rainforest of the Taipo River.

column3: Blue Lakes and Tasman Glacier walks
column37: View New Zealand's longest glacier, the mighty Haupapa/Tasman Glacier on one of our best short walks.

column3: Ulva Island Te Wharawhara walking tracks
column37: Visit iconic Ulva Island/Te Wharawhara, the jewel of Rakiura National Park. Sample the delights of this open sanctuary via a series of well-formed tracks catering for all ages and levels of fitness.

This classic summer tramp for experienced backcountry trampers crosses Harman Pass, Whitehorn Pass and Browning Pass/Noti Raureka. It gives the excitement, variety and contrast of a transalpine route.
Kashmir Road climbs far and high into Ruahine Forest Park and provides quick access to the high country. Daphne Hut, Awatere Hut and Longview Hut are all accessible by track from the road.
This short walk leads to Mount Damper Falls, one of the highest falls in the North Island.
This challenging tramping route leads from the Milford Road to Glade House on the Milford Track, via Dore Pass.
The track from Maratoto to Golden Cross takes you past an old mining area and a regenerating broadleaf/hardwood forest.
The Kaniere Water Race Walkway provides an opportunity for a pleasant bush walk in an area that is rich in history.
Climb up to Mt McKerrow for a great view of Wellington harbour and the surrounding hills near the top.

column3: Table Flat Kashmir Roadend West East crossing
column37: A west east traverse of the Ruahine Forest Park, following the Oroua River valley and over the main Ruahine Range to the Kashmir Roadend.
The Otaika Valley Walk offers you a variety of landscapes including farmland and native forest.
Enjoy walking along the former Waitengaue bush tramway on this track that takes you to Waitawheta Hut.
This short, easy walk leads through a lush rimu forest to the idyllic Lake Wombat - it's a good option for children.

Rawhiti Cave is nationally significant as it has possibly the most diverse and extensive entrance and twilight-zone flora of any cave in New Zealand.
You can walk onto a viewing platform just inside the cave entrance.

column11: 2 - 3 hr one way | 3 - 4 hr 30 min one way
column37: Scheelite mining history, open tussock country and grand views await on these tracks - with the option of staying overnight in the basic Heather Jock Hut.
Walk or mountain bike along the western shores of Lake Kaniere through lush lakeside forest, passing many picturesque bays and numerous forest streams.
The track at Diamond Creek follows the true left bank of the creek to Lake Reid.

column11: 1 hr 30 min one way from Turere Bridge
column37: The Big Bend Track follows the Orongorongo River and connects the Orongorongo Track with the Whakanui Track.
Enjoy a walk through attractive lowland forest dominated by tawa and rewarewa.
Enjoy a short walk to a magnificant tiered waterfall.
Walk along open grassy terrances and through low coastal scrub to the shoreline of the inner Hokianga Harbour.
The Mangapurua and Kaiwhakauka Tracks are two stages of the Mountains to Sea Cycle Trail. The two tracks have various entry/exit options

This short, easy walk through Otatara Pā has archaeological features from one of the largest and most ancient Māori pā sites, as well as commanding views of the coastline - it's a good option for kids.
With coastal forest, spectacular views and WWII gun emplacements as well - there is plenty to keep kids interested on this short, easy walk.
Walk to the top and down to the base of these spectacular 55 m falls. The track is to the top of the falls is suitable for wheelchairs and buggies.
On this challenging and remote adventure ride, pass through beech forest and enjoy the scenery, streams and wildlife of the Kaimanawa Forest Park.
The Mangamuka Tramping Track takes you through scenic Raetea Forest, a track made for the adventurous at heart.

column3: Piano Flat & Waikaia Forest tramping tracks
column37: Waikaia Forest is a large island of beech forest, nestled in the mountain farmlands of northern Southland. Piano Flat, a grassy enclosure at the southern end, provides a picnic area, camping ground and several walking tracks.
These short walks feature kauri trees and are great for children.

column11: 1 hr 30 min return or 3-4 hr full circuit
column37: Walk to picturesque Makiekie Creek for a picnic and a paddle.

column3: Holdsworth roadend to Powell Hut Mount Holdsworth
column11: Powell Hut: 5 – 6 hr, Mount Holdsworth: 7 – 8 hr
column37: This tramp follows the Mount Holdsworth Track to Powell Hut. From the rocky outcrop below the hut you get a view of High Ridge and Totara Flats far below.
The Kaitake Range is remarkably different from the rest of Egmont National Park with its variety of warmth-loving semi-coastal forest.

column3: Outram Glen to Lee Stream Walk
column37: A very pleasant forested walking track that follows the Taieri River round to the confluence of Lee Stream with the river.
The Motutapu Walkway takes you from Islington Bay on Rangitoto Island across the causeway to Home Bay and Emu Bay on Motutapu Island.
The Karangarua and Douglas valleys offer hunters, trampers and mountaineers many challenging opportunities and rewards within the rugged backcountry environment of Westland Tai Poutini National Park.

This 3 day guided loop for more experienced walkers, takes you along the south coast of New Zealand up to the subalpine Hump Ridge zone, over historic viaducts in the heart of the native forest. Rest in easy-access, comfortable backcountry lodges.
North Block Road walking tracks include the walk to Triple X Hut and the Swamp Track.
Enjoy great views over the Rangitikei River terraces on this short loop walk that's suitable for children.
These short walks pass through dense bush to reach Lake Mahinapua - with a picnic area/campsite at one end, these walks are great for kids.
Motuora is a small island with walks of up to two hours. Walk to the northern end of the island or to Still Bay, a perfect place for a picnic.
Walk to an abandoned bridge in the heart of the Whanganui National Park.
