A 2-hour return walk allows you to visit one of the Coromandel Peninsula’s finest remaining kauri stands, Waiomu Kauri Grove.
This track affords views of Te Waiti Stream and lowland forest and is suitable for a family day trip.

column11: 7 hr to Port Craig, 4 days to Big River
column37: This track of varying difficulty leads along rugged southern Fiordland coast to Port Craig (easy overnight) and beyond to the more remote Big River (4 days one way).

column3: Mikonui Catchment   Dickie Ridge Upper Tuke River Route
column37: The Dickie Ridge/Tuke River Route provides a link to challenging alpine tramping opportunities and gives access to the Waitaha and Whitcombe catchments.
Fit trampers can climb the tallest peak in the Remutaka range (941m) and the nearest to Wellington.

View a community of wading birds, fish, mud dwellers and aquatic plant life from the estuary track and boardwalk. Over 70 species of resident and migratory waterbirds use the estuary as a feeding and resting area.
A 3-day loop with marvellous views from sub-alpine tops and rugged coastline in southern Fiordland. Hut bookings required.
It is well worth the effort getting out the car and stretching your legs with a day hike up Dromedary Hill.
Large grassed areas on the banks of the Manganui River, makes this a popular picnic and swimming area.
Walk a loop track in Glory Cove Scenic Reserve on Stewart Island/Rakura.

column3: Lake Emma to Lake Camp Track
column37: Walk or mountain bike to an old musterers hut near Lake Emma.

column11: 1 hr 45 min to the summit one way
column37: Take a walk to the summit of Mount Auckland (Atuanui) through regenerating native forest. At the summit you’ll have panoramic views of Kaipara Harbour and Hoteo River Estuary.
Spot New Zealand fur seals/kekeno and yellow-eyed penguins/hoiho from this cliff-top walk.
Climb to the summit of Patutu (1162 m) for great views of the coast and the North Island.
Looking for day walks from the Mavora Lakes camping ground in the Te Anau area? Try the South Mavora Lake Walking Track or the track to the Kiwiburn Hut.
Follow the gentle incline of an historic coach road through the heart of the Mataraua Forest.

column3: Dome Forest car park to lookout
column37: Starting from the Dome tearooms carpark, steps lead up along a narrow road reserve to the Dome Forest conservation area.
For a taste of the Routeburn Track Great Walk or for an easy overnight tramp with kids, walk to Lake Howden with plenty of mountain and valley views along the way.

A stunning, well surfaced, coastal walkway. Enjoy walking through varied and interesting forest to a panoramic, cliff top viewing platform. Point Elizabeth track is a perfect walk for families and children.

Enjoy 360 degree views of the Bay of Islands from this important historic site - the Union Jack was first flown here in 1840, then chopped down four times up till 1845 as a symbolic gesture against British rule.
Enjoy one of the walks around historic, man-made Blue Lake in St Bathans and view sluicings and gold mining remains.
The track starts from Fantail Falls, crosses the Haast River, and climbs steadily through beech forest to the bushline.
This well-graded track follows a section of the old Bridle Track, the first link between Otago and Westland.
View the spectacular Motu Falls from the car park and picnic area, or walk along an old coach road through native forest - suitable for all ages.
This track starts and finishes at Aickens car park beside SH73, 5 km west of Otira township.
Climb to the top of Lodestone (1462 m) and enjoy spectacular views of Tasman Bay and the Arthur Range.

column11: 6 hr to hut, then 4 - 5 hrs to bushline
column37: This difficult tramping track leads to a hut, then a route heads for the bushline at Lake Monowai, Fiordland.
The Jollie Brook Circuit starts and finishes off Lake Sumner Road, in Lake Sumner Forest Park.
Walk through recovering wetland and remnant of flooded forest on this short, easy loop walk - it's a good option for kids.
Trampers are well rewarded for their effort from the upper sections of the greater Grandview Range with inspiring views over Lakes Hāwea and Wanaka and mountains beyond.
A two- to three-day tramping track through an upland valley in Hāwea Conservation Park. It also provides access to Ahuriri Conservation Park.
With suspension bridges, a stream, a waterfall and a nice spot for a picnic, this track has plenty to keep kids entertained.
The Alpine Nature Walk in Lewis Pass provides an opportunity to break up a long drive while enjoying spectacular scenery and beech forest.
Pedalling Otago’s rural heart. The famous Rail Trail takes you through traditional country towns and sheep-farming land farmed by families for many generations.
Walk to the Matai Falls (10 m) through regenerating podocarp and broadleaf forest.
Trek across a volcanic alpine landscape of dramatic contrasts – steaming vents, glacial valleys, ancient lava flows, alpine vegetation and vivid crater lakes, all with stunning views.
This challenging tramping route from Hollyford Road to the West Coast offers an adventure for experienced and well equipped trampers. Combine with the Hollyford Track for a 10 day round trip.
From Lake Hāwea the track follows the Timaru River, crosses Mount Martha Saddle and descends into the Ahuriri Valley. It's a demanding tramp for experienced parties.

column3: Clarke Flat & Te Wanahu Flat tracks
column37: Discover a variety of vegetation and a waterfall on these walks - shorter options are suitable for children.
Enjoy a short journey through the rainforest to a lookout to get a great view of Fox Glacier Te Moeka o Tuawe.
Experience stunning views over Queen Charlotte Sound and spot some native birds on this walk up to the island's summit.
This is an easy loop walk through bush a short distance from Palmerston North - it's a good option for families with children.
This short walk features great views and access to a small beach - with a pa site to explore as well this easy walk is a great option for children.
This track climbs up to St Paul's Rock, which stands high above Whangaroa township and provides spectacular views of the Whangaroa Harbour. It's suitable for those with moderate fitness.
It will take you six hours of moderate to hard walking to complete the Ruapani Circuit. The track is accessed from the Waikareiti Track and passes through beautiful forest and seven wetlands.
A track climbs from Ahuriri valley over Dingleburn Pass and descends to Top Dingle Hut in Dingle Burn valley.
This well-defined track leads through old moraine river terraces and tall red beech/tawhai raunui to pretty Lake Sylvan in Mount Aspiring National Park.
The Cape Brett Track traverses rugged terrain for 16 km through native and regenerating bush. Expect dramatic coastal views; steep cliffs and drop-offs to the side of the track are a feature.
A steep overnight tramp with magnificent views through open tussock land.
Butcher Track provides magnificent views of the Wellington harbour and surrounding areas.

column3: Lake Hauroko to Teal Bay Hut Track
column37: This rather difficult tramping track in the Lake Hauroko area goes around the lake via bays and bush-clad ridges towards Teal Bay Hut.
A number of tracks lead to a hut at Lake Christabel.
Enjoy impressive views of stunning Milford Sound from a lookout on this short, easy walking track.

Enjoy the awe-inspiring landscapes of the Southern Alps/Kā Tiritiri o te Moana on one of our best day hikes - wind up the Hooker Valley past alpine streams and glaciers in the shadow of Aoraki/Mount Cook.

column11: 20 min return to falls, 3 hr return to lake
column37: Enjoy this tramping track from Hollyford Road (off Milford Road) to beautiful Lake Marian - an alpine lake in a beautiful hanging valley.
Walk within a flooded canyon to a shady picnic or fishing spot near Lake Aviemore in the Waitaki Valley.
This loop walking and mountain biking track meanders along the upper slopes of the Clutha river and offers spectacular views of surrounding peaks and Otago landscapes.
Marawaiwai Track runs alongside a meandering stream through kahikitea forest. It is suitable for all the family.

column11: 20 min one way | 40 min one way
column37: Stroll to a small waterfall or picnic along a sparkling stream and listen to the bird song.
Explore tussock terraces in the Potts River area.
Discover 'goblin forest' on this short walk.
Walk to a large kauri tree - it's suitable for children but not for buggies.
A short walking track from Ferry Landing Wharf leads into Whitianga Rock Scenic and Historic Reserve where you can visit the remains of a pa site.
Aorere Goldfields Track is a 3-hour loop, which gives you access to explore some of the more accessible gold-mining remnants.
Opera Point on the Coromandel Peninsula offers a walk on an old tramway line to a pleasant beach.
The western slopes of the mountain are known for their very high rainfall, resulting in numerous wet and boggy areas.
The short Pā Road Walk links Pā Road to the Kerikeri Basin.
The Gibbston River Trail is a walking and mountain bike track that stretches 11km from the historic Kawarau Suspension Bridge along the south bank of the Kawarau River.
The Mount Taranaki summit should only be attempted in good weather by experienced trampers with proper equipment.
Built by miners in the 1880s, the Invincible Gold Mine Track is an uphill walk that offers wonderful views of the Rees Valley and Mt Earnslaw/Pikirakatahi.
The Brynderwyn Hills stretch from Mangawhai Heads on the east coast nearly halfway to the eastern arms of the Kaipara Harbour. You can access the walk from either its western or eastern ends.
Take a 3-hour return walk along the Okura Bush Walkway. The walkway winds its way through the Okura River Estuary and through coastal forest to Karepiro Bay and historic Dacre Cottage.

column3: Pearl Harbour to Hope Arm Track
column37: The track leads through beech forest to a very pleasant bay on Lake Manapouri, with a great swimming spot and hut.
This is pleasant walk uphill through changing alpine rainforest, with an optional detour to a lookout point offering views of the mountain and out to the coast.
Walk to the beautiful Waiotemarama waterfall (20 m) and on through a hardwood forest and kauri stand for a longer loop walk.
Walk to these 40 m falls surrounded by thick walls of moss and ferns.
Enjoy views of Cobb Reservoir from this track that runs along the ridge above.
Explore Gabriels Gully and the stories of goldfield occupants with a series of interpretation panels as your guide, and picnic at Greys Dam.
Walk through ancient forest, experience spectacular lake vistas, and enjoy constant birdsong on a variety of walks on the southwestern shores of Lake Taupo.
Discover spectacular waterfalls and a rock bivvy in the Canyon Creek area.
Walk through regenerating forest to a trig.

column3: Visitor Centre to Te Anau Bird Sanctuary Walk
column37: Enjoy an easy walk along the lakeside in Te Anau that takes you to the bird sanctuary where you can see the rare, flightless takahē, kākā and other birds.
A great opportunity to walk through mature lowland podocarp forest with excellent examples of kahikatea, matai, miro and totara.
These short forest walks lead to picnic areas, waterfalls and sandy beaches ideal for swimming - plenty to keep kids interested.
Walk or mountain bike the Government Track which traverses the slopes of the beech-and mānuka-forested Waipori Valley.
These short tramping tracks travel through mountain beech forest.
This circuit via Old Man Hut makes a good weekend tramp.
Explore defences that were placed on the headland to protect Auckland from feared Russian invasions.
This easy loop walking track skirts a swampy area close to Lake Hauroko in southern Fiordland.
Inland Track travels through regenerating and undisturbed forest where tui, bellbirds and other wildlife can be seen. Occasional granite outcrops offer excellent views of the coast.
This easy walk follows a short section of the former railway line that ran from Nelson towards Murchison.
Following Earnslaw Burn through bush to the tussock basin at the head of this valley for impressive views of an icefall on Mt Earnslaw/Pikirakatahi.
Trace the shoreline of Lake Waikaremoana, the 'sea of rippling waters.' Pass giant podocarp trees and remote beaches, and enjoy breathtaking views from Panekire Bluff.

This delightful short walk follows a stream through the rainforest - it's a great introduction to the forest for children with the added bonus of glow worms at night. It's suitable for wheelchairs and buggies.
Enjoy native bush and quiet beaches. The track provides good opportunities to look out over the Blue Lake (Tikitapu) and Green Lake (Rotokakahi).

column3: Tui Track link from Boyle village
column37: From Boyle village on SH7, you can pick up tracks that link the end of the St James Walkway with tracks in Hope valley and Doubtful River, Lake Sumner Forest Park.
Located near Russell, this short walk traverses Toretore Island. It takes you through a young totara forest with views of the inner Bay of Islands and Paihia's off-shore islands.
Arohaki Lagoon is one of the must see sites in the Whirinaki.

Experience wild Fiordland on one of our best short walks - wander through red beech forest, enjoying glimpses of the birdlife of the Eglinton valley, Lake Gunn and the surrounding mountains. It's a good option for children.
Take a walk to the Moeraki Boulders - geological marvels, exposed by erosion of sedimentary rocks laid down from 65 to 13 million years ago.
This one hour walk will lead you around Lake Kaitawa, a small lake to the south of Lake Waikaremoana. Along the way take the track to Green Lake and Fairy Springs.
Walk to the tallest recorded native tree in New Zealand.
The Moonlight/Croesus Route gives panoramic views of the Paparoa Ranges.
The Wharekirauponga Track in Parakawai Valley and the Royal Standard Goldmine area follows along an old horse-drawn tram track.
Doubtful valley in Lake Sumner Forest Park can be reached from beside SH 7 (Lewis Pass highway) about 165 km drive from Christchurch.
Walk to a cascading waterfall and enjoy gorgeous views out to the coast.
Meander your way through bush from Te Wairoa to Hot Water Beach Campsite. Stay overnight or pre-book a water taxi to The Landing.
Walk around Hawksbury lagoon in Waikouaiti and enjoy this wildlife refuge providing habitat for ducks and native birds which can be seen from the causeways that cross the pools.
The walk to Packhorse Hut can be enjoyed as a half day walk but is also a great overnight tramp for families with children and new trampers.

column11: 1 hr 20 min one way | 3 hr 30 min - 4 hr return
column37: Walk one way from Dawson Falls to Stratford Plateau or complete a circuit back to Dawson Falls.
The narrow Makahu Road provides access to the Makino and Middle Hill huts.
The Upper Copland Valley Track provides access to Douglas Rock Hut. It is suitable for well-equipped and experienced backcountry trampers and mountaineers only.
Walk to the well known and often photographed Purakaunui Falls.
The Lake Waikareiti Walk will take you two hours to complete a return trip. Along the way you may hear the screech of the kaka and the chatty ki-ki-ki of the yellow-crowned parakeet (kakariki).
The Moeraki Valley offers good tramping for the fit and experienced. The U-shaped valley is typical of those carved out by glaciers during repeated glacial periods.
This tramping track in Kenepuru Sound follows a ridge to the summit (1203 m), the highest point in the Sounds.
This track gives access to Maryburn Stream, or carry on further to Simons Hill.

column3: Buskin Highcliff and Paradise Road tracks
column37: Walk or mountain bike tracks from Highcliff Road.

This walkway follows an old goldminer's trail across the range between the Wairau Valley and Linkwater. It can be walked or ridden in one day, but you will need to arrange transport between the road ends.
Pass through attractive native bush, alongside a stream, to an old dam - it's ideal for children.
Walk to Black Hill Hut on one of these tracks or combine them to make a circuit.
A pleasant walk through regenerating forest to a lookout with stunning views over a valley that is home to kauri trees.

column3: Pearl Harbour return via Circle Track
column37: This tramping track takes you on a pleasant, half-day walk through beech forest near Manapouri, to a hill viewpoint overlooking the lake.
Walk through beautiful forest to Onaia Stream, a tranquil and secluded spot that's ideal for a picnic or to cool off in - with geocaches as well this short walk has plenty to keep kids interested.

column11: 6 - 7 hrs going south, 7- 8 hrs going north
column37: The Mangahao Makahika Track connects Burtton's Track, which lies between Palmerston North and Shannon, with the Arapaepae Lookout Trail near Levin.
The Skyline Track is a challenging tramping track in the Wanaka area.
A public access easement leads to Landslip Creek above Lake Pukaki.

The Whitcombe Pass Track takes you through the very rugged bush clad valleys of the lower Hokitika and Whitcombe Rivers to the Main Divide.  This guide describes the route from the Hokitika road end to Whitcombe Pass only.

This track is for experienced trampers and starts at the Gates of Haast Bridge. Like most of the smaller valleys in this area, the Wills’ lower reaches are gorged, and then open out to flats further up.
See hundreds of wading birds on this family-friendly short walk into the Titri wetands.
Experience stunning views and native bush on Te Arapiki o Tawhaki at Pukaha Mount Bruce.
Tramping track for experienced trampers with good route-finding abilities. The route descends to the Waipapa River.
Explore a limestone landscape of pancake-shaped rock formations, blowholes and surge pools on this short, paved walk that's great for children.
Situated near the Hāwea River Swing Bridge this small loop track around the Butterfields Wildlife Management Area is suitable for biking, running and walking.

column3: Teal Bay to South Coast Track
column37: This difficult tramping track heads from the southern shore of Lake Hauroko, over alpine tops on Hump Ridge and down to the coast at Te Waewae Bay.
Stroll among small lakes with lovely reflections of the Earl Mountains on this easy, short walk off Milford Road - it's great for children.
Enjoy excellent views of the blue-green waters of the Hokitika River as it makes its way through the rock sided Hokitika Gorge - this short, easy walk is a great option for kids.
This short, easy walk passes through regenerating native forest to Kororipo pā - it's a great option for children to explore the heritage of early Maori/European settlement.
Explore Otanewainuku Forest on these short walks - there's an easier option for families with children.
Western Okataina Walkway is open for both walking and mountain biking.
Learn about forest plant life from information signs on this easy walk.
This forest track follows an old route where logs were once hauled to Yeoman’s Mill. It is open to walkers and mountain bikers.

column3: A Frame Hut & Takapari Road Track
column37: Head to Tamaki Road end by following the track up through forest to Takapari Road. From there you’ll follow a bulldozed road 100 m to the hut.
The climb to the top of Peak Hill rewards walkers with sweeping views of Lake Coleridge and its surrounds. The walk is extremely exposed to the weather and walkers should be well equipped.
The Willberg Walk in Harihari climbs gently through rimu forest.
Discover Te Ana or Tangoio Falls on a short, easy walk suitable for kids, or take a longer walk through native bush on the Tangoio Walkway.
There are a variety of options for day or overnight trips from Kuripapango/Castle Rocks Road. Some are round trips and some link with other road ends or access points to Kaweka Forest Park.
A challenging climb to an isolated rock outcrop in the Kaimai Ranges that offers spectacular views across the valley.
The walk provides a good introduction to the rainforest of the Glacier Region as well and an opportunity to see glow worms after dark - it's a great option with children.

column3: Renfrew Roadend to Table Flat Roadend
column37: Climb up and over the tussock tops of the Whanahuia Range in Ruahine Forest Park then drop down to follow the Oroua River valley.

column3: Orokawa Scenic Reserve short walking tracks
column37: There are a number short walks you can enjoy in the Orokawa Scenic Reserve.
Walk through coastal forest to an attractive beach.
Walk to a spectacular blowhole with exploding waves and roaring sound effects.

The Caples and Greenstone tracks start from the car park at the end of Greenstone Road, 86 km from Queenstown, via Glenorchy. Alternatively, they can be started from Howden Hut on the Routeburn Track.
This track leads to Lake Christabel.
Winding through stunted beech forest, the Whakapapaiti Valley Track makes its way to the Whakapapaiti Hut. From here you can continue in a loop back to Whakapapa Village.
Enjoy this easy day walk along the Hollyford Track to the beautiful Hidden Falls or the nearby hut for lunch.
This little gem of a hut is tucked away in Ahuriri Conservation Park.
The cliff top walk from Bethells Beach (Te Henga) to south of Muriwai Beach (or reverse) reveals stunning views of Auckland's wild west coast.
This easy, short walking track is suitable for all ages, wandering from the Milford Road through forest to peaceful Lake Mistletoe.
Fowlers Pass (1296 m) connects Fowlers Hut on Tophouse Road with Stanley Vale and Lake Guyon huts in the St James Conservation Area.
Walk through an impressive limestone gorge that passes underneath a 17 m high natural arch.
This popular, easy walk passes through different forest types and has swimming holes at the end of the track - it's ideal for families.
An interesting walk in the Taieri Gorge that travels alongside the Taieri River and passes through several different types of vegetation.

You can stroll the boardwalk, walk the loop track through wetland tarns or walk along the spectacular white quartz beach to the outlet of Waituna Lagoon. Waituna is a Ramsar site so is internationally recognised place of importance for birdlife.
This walking track in Deep Cove, Doubtful Sound, is a short, self guided nature walk through forest to the Helena Falls lookout.
This is an east-west crossing of the Kaimai Ranges used since the 1890s linking Katikati and Te Aroha. It can be walked in either direction.

column3: Teal Bay to Lake Poteriteri Hut Route
column37: This challenging tramping route travels through remote southern Fiordland forested valleys between Lake Hauroko and Lake Poteriteri.

column3: White Pine Bush Scenic Reserve walks
column37: Experience New Zealand's remaining coastal forest on these short, easy walks that are good for children.
This is a great walk for families with young children or those people new to tramping. The track is a well formed bench track that can also be completed as a day walk.
The Southern Crossing is one of the four classic tramps of the Tararua Range.
Waiau Pass Track follows the true right of the Waiau River, St James Conservation Area.

The rugged beauty of New Zealand’s coast unfolds with panoramic views offering spectacular photo opportunities along this walk from the shoreline to the clifftops. It's suitable for children and is one of our best short walks.

column3: Mangleton Road to Park s Peak Ridge
column37: It’s a 2-3 hour walk from Mangleton Road to Park’s Peak Ridge. The track links to Ruahine Range and Golden Crown Ridge to the north and Park's Peak and Upper Makaroro huts to the south.

column11: 30 min one way | 2 hr one way
column37: Walk across farmland to the expansive Ripiro Beach.
This is the ultimate alpine adventure, weaving through meadows, reflective tarns and alpine gardens. You'll be rewarded with spectacular vistas over vast mountain ranges and valleys.
Several times a day the gates at the Aratiatia dam are opened to release the full flow of the river, a spectacular sight from the lookout points - kids will love it!

column3: Whataroa Butler and Perth valleys tracks
column37: The Whataroa, Butler and Perth river valleys tracks and routes provide rugged backcountry opportunities for those with suitable skills and experience.
A 1 hour 30 minutes return walk, the Waiatiu Falls Track in Whirinaki Te Pua-a-Tāne Conservation Park leads through podocarp forest before reaching the picturesque falls.
Find out about walking and mountain biking on the Gibbs Hill Track in Abel Tasman National Park.
Enjoy great views up the mountain and down to the Taranaki Ring Plain and the coastline on route to picturesque Lake Dive.

column3: Pearl Flat to head of the valley
column37: This track climbs through beech forest crossing swingbridges to bring you to the head of the Matukituki Valley.
Mount Urchin offers an easily accessible wilderness of beautiful beech forest, incredible views and a real alpine environment.
Starting in Mt Hutt Forest and ending at Mount Hutt Skifield Road, Scotts Saddle Track offers beautiful views over mid-Canterbury.
Isolated Hill Scenic Reserve is typical South Marlborough: rugged bluffs and steep, dry hills drained by stony rivers.
East Ahuriri Track is part of Te Araroa.
Located on the western shore of Lake Taupo, this track allows walking access to one of the most stunning bays on the lake.
View the very large Londonderry Rock - which during the Kumara Goldrushes was too large for miners to move or break.
This popular walk leads to Pinnacles Hut, and on to the summit of the Pinnacles with spectacular views of the Coromandel Peninsula. It can be completed as a day or overnight walk.
Harihari Coastal Walkway is one of the most scenic walkways on the West Coast, with spectacular views of forest, rivers, mountains and coastline.
Walk through native bush, enjoy scenic views and experience native wildlife only a short distance from Palmerston North.
This difficult tramping track between Lake Hauroko and Lake Manapouri offers huge lakes, gushing rivers, vast forested valleys and lots of mud for experienced and well equipped trampers.
This easy walk takes you through regenerating forest and by the remains of an old timber dam before coming to a viewing area.
Enjoy dramatic coastal views from the Tokata Lighthouse and spot seals, penguins and other seabirds on these short walks.
This fascinating forest track passes by tailraces and dams and through tunnels built by gold miners in the 19th century.

The Mount Somers Track provides a number of options, including for kids, for an overnight tramp with impressive rock formations, historic mines and stunning views. It links the popular Pinnacles and Woolshed Creek huts.
The Leslie–Karamea Track is one of the region’s premier semi-wilderness experiences, situated in the middle of Kahurangi National Park.
Climb through Kaihu Forest to the top of Mount Tutamoe and you will be rewarded by stunning, panoramic views.
An easy walk through a podocarp and broadleaf forest remnant with impressive specimens of rimu, totara and kahikatea - great for kids and they can earn a Kiwi Guardians medal too!
This tramping track, taking 2-3 days to complete, forms part of the Te Araroa - The Long Pathway and connects to the Timaru River Track.
Climb to the picturesque glacial Lake Alta.
Take a short walk to Quartz Reef Point, the best preserved example of herring bone tailings in the country.
This track is dominated by the majestic Mount Tarawera.
The challenging Around the Mountain Circuit (AMC) offers you spectacular bush and alpine scenery. It is best tramped from October to April.
This difficult tramping track leads from the Milford Road and up the Mistake Creek Valley through beech forest to the river flats.
An easy to moderate overnight tramp to Rangiwahia Hut on the Whanahuia Range in Ruahine Forest Park. Return via the open tops and Deadman’s Track.
This tramping track offers an easy walk from the Borland Lodge grounds to Lake Monowai, in Fiordland.
Stroll, walk, run or cycle around a lake surrounded by spectacular mountains.

column3: Borland Road to Monowai Hut Track
column37: This tramping track leads from Borland Saddle to a hut at the northern end of Lake Monowai in Fiordland National Park.

column3: Alice Nash Memorial Heritage Lodge Track
column37: This track in the scenic Oroua River valley can be enjoyed as a half day tramp but it's also a good overnight tramp for families with children and new trampers.
This short walk goes through an excavated tunnel kids will love, to a secluded beach and a spectacular, rocky coastline.
This is an easy wander suitable for children. The loop track leads you through a beautiful kauri forest with a chance to see glow-worms.

column3: Okiwi Bay Half Moon Bay Track
column37: Walk or mountain bike through varied vegetation and enjoy ocean views.

This easy track follows the first part of the Kepler Track (a Great Walk) around the Te Anau lake shore to two lovely swimming and picnicking - it's great for children and they can earn a Kiwi Guardians medal too! Catch a water taxi one way for a shorter
The Ketetahi Track is a section of the Tongariro Alpine Crossing. You can get close up views of the active Te Maari craters.
Enjoy sweeping panoramic views of the Canterbury Plains, Banks Peninsula and the Southern Alps/Kā Tiritiri o te Moana from Mt Thomas (1023 m).
Escape on an island adventure - relax and unwind in the peaceful surroundings with the bush, birds and beach at your side.
This walk takes you out onto coastal dunes then back through the bush to your starting point.
This challenging tramping route from the Hollyford Road climbs the slope to meet the Routeburn Track near Harris Saddle.
This cliff top track, through farm land and regenerating forest, offers great coastal views.
Discover interesting flora and panoramic views at the top of Te Ahumata (398 m).
This track highlights the area's incredible native forest and cultural importance.  Beautiful beach at Korokitewao Bay (Lake Rotoiti) for swimming and picnicking.
The Ewe Range Track provides walking access to the northern end of Oteake Conservation Park.
The Ohau Stream Walk is unsafe due to earthquake damage and is closed until further notice.
This walk follows a shallow creek through a mixture of native bush and exotics before crossing farmland.
The Wangapeka route crosses Kahurangi National Park - it crosses two saddles and travels through the beautiful beech-forested valleys.
The Kidds Bush Nature Walk is an enjoyable loop track through a mountain beech forest.
The Otoko Walkway is 50 km north-west of Gisborne. The track traverses 5 km of the old Gisborne/Moutohora railway line and takes 2.5 hours one way.
This short track takes you to lookout with views of the spectacular Te Reinga Falls.

column3: Masters Shelter to Golden Crown Ridge
column37: The Golden Crown Ridge Track begins behind Master Shelter. The 2-3 hour walk climbs around a series of rocky knolls before continuing steeply upwards through beech forest to the top of the range.
The Loop Track is a short walk orientated towards families or school groups to provide an experience close to town showcasing the beautiful flora and fauna of Mt Ngongotaha for all to see.
Walk along the Ngamoko Track as it steadily climbs to the Ngamoko Range summit. You will be rewarded for your hard work by the views at the summit.

column11: 8-9 hr or shorter walks from 20 min to 2 hr
column37: Beautiful native forest and gold-mining relics are the main attractions of the Kaituna Valley. To walk the whole track takes 8-9 hours, or there are shorter walks from 20 minutes to 2 hours.
Enjoy a wide range of tracks, from an easy, fun cycle with the family along Railway Track, to a steep 50-minute walk to the Whitehorse monument with great views out over Waimate.
You can see some of the Bay of Plenty's remnant kauri giants on this track.
The route links the Aorere and Cobb valleys in Golden Bay. It is unmarked and suitable for trampers with a high degree of fitness and off-track experience.
Enjoy some of the best views in Canterbury from the summit of Mt Grey/Maukatere (934 m).
This loop walk passes through ancient forest with towering trees and a beautiful stream - with interpretation signs as well this is a great option for children.
Take a steep climb through forest to the rocky open knolls of Maharahara high point in the Ruahine Forest Park.
This tramping track leads to a hut at attractive Green Lake in Monowai, Fiordland.
Follow in the footsteps of old goldminers on the Wakamarina Track to cross the Richmond Range from the Wairau Valley to the Wakamarina Valley.
Follow the Waitōtara River to Trains Hut.
Tucked away under the Ohau Range lies this short track through mountain beech forest.

Walk to Cooks Cove where Captain James Cook stopped in 1769 as part of his circumnavigation of New Zealand - with information panels, a hole-in-the-wall, and a safe cove to swim in, this walk is a good option for children.
Follows Ashley River to Youngman Stream Hut.
This family walking and cycling track follows the route of the former Ngaruawahia/Glen Massey railway to attractive stream cascades.
Two short walking tracks leaving from the Bryant Memorial Reserves.
This short walking track takes you to Rarawa beach.

This track goes right around Moturua Island. You can join the track at any of the main beaches and walk through open grassy areas and along cool shady stretches beneath the regenerating coastal forest trees.
These short walks in and around Talbot Forest Scenic Reserve are ideal for families. There are four short walks through the forest which interconnect with roads around the reserve.

With viewing platforms that provide great views of magnificent  waterfalls and white water rafters making their way down the Kaituna River, as well as geocaches and glow worms at night, there is plenty to keep kids entertained on this short, easy walk.
Enjoy panoramic views from various points on this track, as well as from a lookout point at the top (290 m).
The Aramoana Boardwalk and saltmarsh experience, and other short walks from Aramoana on the edge of Otago Harbour, suit  all ages and abilities.
Climb onto the St Arnaud Range for spectacular views of the surrounding area.

column3: Toaroha Zit Saddle Kokatahi Lathrop Saddle Styx River Route
column37: This route traverses alpine ridges and crosses two alpine saddles. It demands experience and good route finding skills in other than fine weather conditions.
Explore the area around Lake Pukaki on these short walking tracks.
Walk the length of the Hakarimata Range and enjoy excellent views towards the coast and across the Waikato Basin.
This is a well-marked track through established bush with valley views and large kauri trees. This track connects with the Waipapa River Track.
An easy short walk to a lookout point with panoramic views over the southern end of Lake Taupo.
After walking up the valley, a challenging track crosses the Matukituki River and climbs through bush to tussock slopes in the sub-alpine zone.
This easy walk in the Omahuta Kauri Sanctuary will take you to the stump and head of one of the largest kauri ever felled in the Omahuta Forest.
This loop walk climbs to vantage points with spectacular views - farmland, a beach and gun emplacements will keep kids interested.
Access the Remarkables Conservation Area on these tracks.
Wakarara Road End tramping tracks include tracks to Poutaki Hut, Parks Peak Hut and Sparrowhawk Bivouac and the Colenso Spur to the Main Range track.
Take in spectacular views of Whangaroa Harbour from Duke's Nose.
An easy walk, ideal for families, in beautiful Whakaipo Bay. Take a picnic and spend the day on the beach.
One of the bush walks at Mimiwhangata, the track leads you to the top of the ridge with impressive views of the peninsula and out towards the Poor Knights Islands.

column3: Dome Forest car park to Waiwhiu Grove
column37: From the Dome Forest lookout the track continues to the Dome Summit where you get views of Taranga Island.
The Dingle Burn Peninsula Track is a pleasant walk to the Turihuka Conservation Area. It also provides access into Hāwea Conservation Park via the Dingle Burn and Hunter River Tracks.
The Motatapu Track follows much of an historic route that linked the Wanaka and Arrowtown areas. It's a demanding alpine tramp for experienced parties.
Angelus, at 1,650 metres, is perched high on the ranges between Lakes Rotoiti and Rotoroa in Nelson Lakes National Park.
The H Tree Track in Whirinaki Te Pua-a-Tāne Conservation Park is a 45-minute loop track that meanders through podocarp forest. The forest is home to a number of native birds, including kaka.
A steep climb to this hut nestled above the bushline on the Hikurangi Range in the Ruahine Forest Park.

column3: Taipo River Track to Harman Pass
column37: The Taipo Valley is often travelled as part of a popular route from the Waimakariri River via Harman Pass. This guide describes the route from SH73 to Harman Pass only.
Walk to an old mine entrance and a restored battery - there are other relics from gold mining days as well so plenty to keep kids entertained.
Follow the Mangakawa Stream with views of waterfalls and small gorges.
Explore the rugged range of rolling hills covered in sub alpine bush.

column11: Northern access: 9 hr, Southern access 7 hr
column37: At 1875m Mt Owen is the highest peak in Kahurangi National Park and on a fine day the views from this peak are spectacular.
This mainly unmarked loop route travels the Leatham Conservation Area and into the magnificent Molesworth Station Recreation Reserve, traversing mountain tops and tussocky valleys.
This walking and mountain biking track passes through native and pine forest from Penzance Bay to Elaine Bay.
Warren's Track is a gently graded climb to a waterfall and good swimming spots.
Enjoy views of Lake Clearwater from the lake shore or the nearby Mount Guy (1319 m).
The limestone features and native vegetation in the Tawarau Forest can best be seen by walking on one of the forest's scenic tracks.
Explore pack tracks and tramlines from gold mining days - the shorter option is suitable for children and follows New Zealand’s oldest known railway (1882-83) with the original rail still in place.
Walk to Sandfly Bay and combine coastal views with wildlife viewing - kids will love the sand dunes and can earn a Kiwi Guardians medal here too.
Discover the spectacular Marian Falls on this easy, short walking track from Hollyford Road, off Milford Road.
Crossing the beautiful Herangi Range, this alternative track leads to Leitch's Hut.
Discover the site of the Kauri Timber Company sawmill and an historic steam traction engine.
Follow in the footsteps of Northland's Māori ancestors. This challenging track climbs through coastal forest before revealing a spectacular 360-degree panorama. It's one of our best day hikes.
Cross through farmlands and native forest before climbing up a steep ridge and bringing you back to the forest entrance. An easier family friendly option is available.
A short climb with rewarding views of the glacier, mountains and river flats.
This route up the braided river-bed of the Waimakariri leads to a comfortable hut situated below the park’s highest peaks. Carrington Hut is a good base for exploring the upper Waimakariri catchment.
Baikie Hut makes a great picnic or overnight venue.

column3: Mt Fyffe and the Seaward Kaikoura Range
column37: Summer-bare or plastered with winter’s snowy coat, Mount Fyffe and the Seaward Kaikoura Range dominate the Kaikoura skyline. They provide recreation opportunities ranging from a family stroll to a serious backcountry journey.
Enjoy views over a geothermal area on this short walk near Rotorua.
The Tramline Track system traverses most of Great Barrier island at its widest point.

column3: Lake Dispute to Moke Lake Track
column37: From Lake Dispute you can walk to Moke Lake.
You can see many historic gold mining features from Atleys Track and there are superb views from the summit of Mt Dewar.

column3: Matiri Valley and 1000 Acre Plateau tramping tracks
column37: It is a 3 hour walk to Lake Matiri. From there you can do overnight tramps to 1000 Acre Plateau.
Walk the beautiful loop track for views of Pelorus Sound and Havelock and the short lookout track for views of Mahua Sound.
Climb up to the summit of Mount Royal (1366 m).
There are a number of tramping tracks in the Harataonga area, which offer great views of the island and surrounding coastline.
This pleasant, easy walk is a chance for children to explore the bush and the shore.
Walk or cycle through bush from Fox Glacier township to the Fox Glacier car park.
Visit New Zealand's largest known living kauri tree, Tāne Mahuta on this short, easy walk suitable for buggies and children.
Explore a network of underground passages.

column3: Meeting of the Waters Scenic Reserve walks
column37: Enjoy a picnic and take one of the short walks in this family friendly reserve.
You can hear and sometimes see kōkako and other birds on the Mapara Track.
This side trip off Ahuriri valley provides the opportunity to scale Ben Avon Peak in Ahuriri Conservation Park.
Walk through magnificent ancient forest on this flat, easy walk.
Ruakaka Pipeline Road Track is considered suitable for people of most fitness levels. The 3-km track provides back dune access to Bream Bay.
A well defined track leads to a small clearing beside Te Puke's original water source.
The Old Maori Trail is also know as the Rosie Bay - Lake Kaitawa Track and follows what was once a Maori trail to the lake.
Enjoy fabulous views and plenty of birdlife on this short, well-formed, well-marked track - with a picnic area as well this is a great option with children.

column11: 3-4 hr to Ben Lomond Saddle, 6-8 hr to Ben Lomond
column37: The Ben Lomond Track is a demanding climb, but on clear days trampers are rewarded at the summit with spectacular panoramic views.
Climb onto a razor back ridge in the Waima Ranges for sensational views and pristine vegetation.
Perched on the northern end of the Hikurangi Range in Ruahine Forest Park, McKinnon Hut is accessed via a long ridge climbing up from the Kawhatau Valley. Stay a night and return the same way.
Take a short stroll to a picnic spot in this reserve renowned for its unique and rare and endangered flora.

column3: Mount Hikurangi   Te Ara ki Hikurangi
column37: Visit the sacred mountain of Ngāti Porou, the highest non-volcanic mountain in the North Island.
This family walk starts from the pleasant Glentui picnic area.
A 250 metre wheelchair accessible walkway has been built into the heart of White Pine Bush Scenic Reserve.
Walk to the cave and deep, clear pool where the Riuwaka River emerges from the depths of the Takaka Hill.
Walk to the top of Mount Sunday for expansive views of the surrounding countryside.
Walk to the five-tier Ryde Falls.
Enjoy extensive views of the Ellis Basin and the surrounding mountains on this track to Ellis Hut.
A short, steep track from the summit of Kennedy Bay Road, Coromandel Peninsula, leads to the Tokatea Lookout.

column3: Visitor Centre to Kepler Track Carpark Walk
column37: This is an easy walking track along Te Anau lake edge to the start of the Kepler Track, with picnic, swimming and photo spots.
Tawa Grove is a bush track specially designed to be an easy walk suitable for all abilities.
From Lawrence Road take a 2-3 hour walk through Blowhard Bush or to Lotkow Shelter. From the shelter follow the Lotkow Track for another 2-3 hours to Lookout and Donald River.
The East Matukituki Valley provides interesting day walks and access to several demanding tramping and climbing routes in Mount Aspiring National Park.
This well formed track offers spectacular views, beautiful bush and one of the largest kauri trees in the Waikato.
This walk around Urupukupuka Island features great views - it's suitable for older children.
The Cobb valley provides options for day and overnight walks with a river and an historic hut to keep kids entertained.
Enjoy this pleasant short walk and get a great view of the glacier and the opportunity to cross a historic suspension bridge.
Walk to the beautiful Wentworth Falls or to views of two mine shafts.
This track follows the Manganuku Stream to the Manganuku Hut.
This 3 hour walk along beautiful Spirits Bay takes you to Pandora where you can stop to observe shore birds or camp for the night.
This is a 50 km, four day tramping trip, linking the Mavora Lakes Camping Area with the Greenstone Track. It passes through open valley tussock land and beech forested hill country.
Explore the volcanic heart of Tongariro National Park, a landscape of stark glacial contrasts and alpine views.
Enjoy the lovely bush walk down to the impressive Coal Creek Falls. A nice place to cool off with a swim in the hot summer months.
The track follows the historic Welshmen’s Water Race through several creeks, then steadily climbs to Ben Cruachan with good views of Lake Wakatipu, the Basin and Nevis Bluff.
This track offers an easy route (achievable by older children) into a dramatic alpine landscape that includes snowfields, glaciers, sheer rock cliffs and waterfalls.
Mount Fox Route is just 3 km south of the town of Fox Glacier. The challenging climb to the top is only suitable for experienced and properly equipped trampers.

column11: 1 hr to hut | 2 hr 30 min loop from hut
column37: Explore the area around Lake Chalice, the only lake in Mount Richmond Forest Park - the short, easy walk to the hut is ideal for an overnight tramp with children.
First-time cavers including children can explore Mangaone Caves - enjoy karst type features, stalactites, stalagmites and calcite wall coverings.
There are plenty of tracks around Lake Ohau for walking and mountain biking. This is a stunning location in both summer and winter.
Take a short walk to a magnificant mature kauri.
This is a pleasant 2 day tramp, crossing easy saddles on well-defined tracks through open mountain beech forest.

column3: Mount Messenger to Kiwi Road Track
column37: This route travels over several ridges and then descends and levels out to open farmland.
This is a daytrip in the southern Tararua Range and the exit/entry to the Kaitoke-Holdsworth Tramp.
This steep track follows the pipeline from the dam and leads you to the foot of a rock bluff. A further walk through beech forest takes you to the stream in the Lower Wye Creek basin.

North of the Franz Josef Township sits the coastal settlement of Ōkārito and the Ōkārito Lagoon. The lagoon is home to more than 76 species of native birds including the kōtuku/white heron and royal spoonbills.
Lake Okataina Scenic Reserve contains fine examples of rimu, totara, rata and kahikatea.  Pohutukawa grace the lake shores, and the reserve is also rich in birdlife.
Walk through native forest to the site of a small defensive pā built and used by Ngati Hia in the late eighteenth century.
This is an excellent full day walk on the Kepler Track (a Great Walk) or overnight tramp to challenge young teenagers - it has swimming beaches, limestone cliffs and glorious mountain and lake views.

The Kauri Block walk on the Coromandel Peninsula follows a ridge through regenerating bush and native plantings. Be sure to walk up the side track which leads you to a pa and offers spectacular views.
This steep tramping track in Deep Cove, Doubtful Sound leads up to an impressive hanging valley and views of the Huntleigh Falls and Deep Cove.
Nestled among mature beech and podocarp forest, these pools of deep, clear water flowing into the Makarora River offer a moment of tranquillity. This is one of our best short walks.
This marked track traverses moraine through beech forest from Lake Sylvan.
The Northern Track links up with other tracks in the Tangihua Forest.
Walk to the beautiful 35 m high Marokopa Falls.
The only walking track up to the summit of Mt Ngongotaha. Passes through native forest with views of one of the largest rata trees in the Bay of Plenty.
This well formed track features rivers, a waterfall, a historic hut/tunnel, native bush and views - plenty to keep kids interested.
Walk through a spectacular stand of kauri and experience the unique character of this ancient forest by day or night.
Climb to the summit of Hakarimata (374 m) and enjoy good views for the summit tower out towards the coast, across the Waikato Basin and down to Ruapehu.
Kids of all ages will be in awe of the towering kauri trees on this easy, short walk - the boardwalk allows for buggies.

Waingongoro Hut is a good overnight tramp for families with children and new trampers - walk through goblin forest, stop for a swim in lava-formed pools, and cross the highest swing bridge in Egmont National Park.
This track leads from the end of Ngamuwahine Road and takes you to a junction with the Leyland O'Brien Tramline Track.
Explore Castlepoint Scenic Reserve by following the boardwalk over the reef and past the lighthouse.
Walk or mountain bike up Mt Patriarch (1656 m).

column11: 1 hr 30 min to Maunganui Bluff | 5 hr to Waikara B
column37: Climb up and over an ancient volcanic crater for some of the best views in the region - pass through some pristine coastal vegetation dominated by Pohutukawa.
This short walking track winds through forest to some of Southland’s largest and oldest tōtara trees in a forest that has never been logged.

column11: 2 hr 30 min - 3 hr 30 min one way
column37: An ideal day hike or easy overnight tramp to a newly replaced hut nestled within Hihitahi Forest Sanctuary north of Taihape.
From the Ferndale campsite there is a 15 minute loop track.
